name: And the Birds Sing by Philip Miletic
description: Thirteen amnesiac women sit in a room and wait for something to happen. They all sit in uncomfortable silence. Sometimes the sound of a match being struck or a lighter’s click breaks the silence. Liz starts snoring. Honey takes out a make-up mirror and re-applies some blush and lipstick. Pursing her lips, she sighs, “I’m bored.” She slouches back into her chair, spreading her legs. “Why are we here?” Born in Grimsby, Ontario, Philip Miletic got his Masters in English at Brock University in St. Catharines and is currently a PhD student at the University of Waterloo. His fiction has appeared in The Danforth Review and dead (g)end(er), his non-fiction in Open Book Toronto and Open Book Ontario, and his poetry has been featured in ditch, Clockwise Cat and Otoliths. He lives in Kitchener, ON. name: Recycled Trophies
description: By Aaron Beebe and Zach Collins, Recycled Trophies is a collection of twenty collages in two states of being: starters and finishes. The two artists, who have never met in person, collaborated over email in a visual conversation where one would start a collage and the other would finish it. The starter collage is presented next to the finished collage. The reader sees how one artist takes the original thought of the other and finishes it by changing its reality completely. In a world where things are not always what they appear to be, where truth lies somewhere in the middle of a dialogue, Recycled Trophies is the perfect comment on contemporary life. About Zach Collins Zach Collins’ collages are a personal expression of time, place, and thought. “I think of it as evidence of experience garnered from found overlooked fragments, discarded objects and vintage imagery collected from off the street, magazines, and second hand stores,” said Collins. “I bring pieces in and out of the composition to see how they react and respond to each other, and rely on instinct and inner experience as I decide what stays and what goes.” Born in Grinnell, Iowa, he studied at Upper Iowa University and the University of Iowa. He is currently living in Minneapolis, Minnesota where he is pursuing an MFA degree at the Minneapolis College of Art and Design. Collins is an active collaborator who as worked with over eighty artists to date. He has exhibited his work internationally. About Aaron Beebe Aaron Beebe's manual, cut-and-paste collages mainly consist of ephemera found through his daily travels. His artwork is made of tangible materials, which is a nice change of pace in a digital world. Beebe, a self-taught artist and design school dropout, divides his time between collaging, screen-printing, and graphic design. Beebe grew up in Virginia Beach, where he was greatly influenced by surf and skate culture. His style stems from a collection of various visual artists like Jean-Michel Basquiat, Andy Warhol, Robert Rauschenberg, David Carson, and more recently, Fred Free, Kareem Rizk, and Brandon McLean. DETAILS: Recycled Trophies | 11.5″ x 8″ | Paperback, saddle-stitched | 44 pages | Maison Kasini Books | 2013 ISBN: 978-1-927587-13-3 Release Date: November 15, 2013 Price: $20.00

name: The Wildest Ponies on the Range
description: "The Wildest Ponies on the Range: Collage by Billy Mavreas & Jp King" is a collection of thirty-six collages made by Jp King and Billy Mavreas as a collaboration in 2010. This publication by Maison Kasini includes all thirty-six collages with an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour. About Jp King The work of Toronto-based Jp King explores contemporary mythology, masculinity, garbage, and collective activity. He studied creative writing at Concordia University. King has exhibited at Whippersnapper Artist-Run Center in Toronto; Galerie Nota Bene and VAV Gallery in Montreal; and in a number of group exhibitions in Montreal, Brooklyn, Halifax, Stockholm, Ottawa, and Toronto. His art and writing has appeared in Kolaj Magazine, Nightlife Magazine, SNAP! Magazine, Décover Magazine, and many others. He was the featured artist in Papirmasse #14 and again in Papirmasse #36. About Billy Mavreas Billy Mavreas is a Montreal based artist and co-director of Monastiraki, a gallery/boutique in the Mile End neighbourhood. His art practice is based on accumulation and accretion, consisting of various personal collections, made and found, that resonate with him on an aesthetic and spiritual level. Mavreas is the author of two graphic novels, one book of posters and countless mini books, prints, zines, pamphlets and assorted ephemera. DETAILS: The Wildest Ponies on the Range | 11.5″ x 8″ | Paperback, saddle-stitched | 40 pages | Maison Kasini Books | 2012 ISBN: 978-1-927587-11-9 Release Date: November 15, 2012 Price: $20.00

description:
In its first year, Kolaj explored collage’s role in the world of contemporary art; asked the question “Is this collage?”; informed readers about collage exhibitions and events; and, most importantly, shined a spotlight on the work of collage artists from around the world.

The Kolaj Year One Collector’s Pack is a collection of the first four issues of the magazine.

With this special offer, you receive Kolaj's first four issues and a one-year subscription beginning with current issue, for a total of eight issues. And if you give this as a gift, we will provide a special card for the recipient.

Shipping included.

Annual Subscription: Four Issues

Kolaj is a quarterly, printed magazine about contemporary collage. We are interested in how collage is made, how collage is exhibited, and how collages is collected. We bring together critical reviews and essays with artist profiles, event highlights, and articles on collage collecting, exhibiting, and making. Kolaj is published in Montreal, Quebec by Maison Kasini and publishes in July, October, January, and April.

Details: 10″x8" | perfect bound | full-colour
ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

Full colour and minimalist design make this one a pleasure to flip through. Kolaj dedicates itself to—you guessed it—the art form of collage. There’s something delightful here: the artistic process famously dependent on cutting up old magazines and newspapers now has a magazine of its own.

name: Art Is Food
description: “You cannot pry apart the two chocolate sides of a Georgia O’Keefe painting and lick the creamy vanilla center. The rampant elements of a de Kooning do not make a nice stew. Do not smear Pollock on your organic buckwheat toast in the morning and wash it down with a cup of steaming hot Andy Warhol. Art is food. Our country is hungry.” In 2006, Ric Kasini Kadour created the artist book Art Is Food, which is based on Kadour’s introduction to Art Town Meeting in Burlington, Vermont (February 2005). During the summer of 2006, Kadour illustrated the text. A hand-pulled screen print was made in Montreal, Quebec in August and September 2006. In 2008, Kasini House Books also published a trade edition. name: Kolaj Year One Collector's Pack
description: In its first year, Kolaj explored collage’s role in the world of contemporary art; asked the question “Is this collage?”; informed readers about collage exhibitions and events; and, most importantly, shined a spotlight on the work of collage artists from around the world. The Kolaj Year One Collector’s Pack is a collection of the first four issues of the magazine. Issue One: Let’s Get This Collage Started Kolaj Editor Benoit Depelteau interviews Boston-based Fred Free whose work is on the cover. Jp King writes about the disfigurative collage of James Gallagher and Sophie Jodoin. We learn that Liz Cohn is playing with a full deck in Portland, Oregon. Billy Mavreas tells us about Felix Morel’s overwhelming visions. Audrey Smith shows us her studio. Portfolios from collage artists in Hartford, Connecticut; Chicago, Illinois; New York City; Madrid, Spain; & Johannesburg, South Africa Issue Two: Is This Collage? Sejma Prodanovic's collage is on the cover. Ric Kasini Kadour tells how Venezuelan collage artist Alejandro Otero brought modernity to his country. Kolaj editor Benoit Depelteau investigates collage as process with artist Emmanuel Laflamme. Billy Mavreas’ “Collage Today & Everyday” explores collage culture. Cory W. Peeke talks with four collage artists about their love of vintage materials. Edvard Derkert comments on urban postering as an act of collage. Ariane Fairlie presents an artist profile of Jessica Korderas, who makes collages in resin. Müge Akçakoca reviews “Cut & Paste” at Gallery Ilayda in Istanbul, Turkey. Cory W. Peeke reviews the artist catalogue Implications: John Hundt. Ric Kasini Kadour reviews Matthew Cusick’s “The Mind Is Its Own Place” at the Pavel Zoubok Gallery. Carolina Chocron shows us her studio. Portfolios from collage artists Belgrade, Serbia; Seattle, Washington, USA; Paris, France; Shropshire, England; and Austin, Texas, USA Issue Three: Fragments & Ideas? On the front cover we feature a work by Toronto artist Jacob Whibley & on the back cover a collage by David King. We take the unusual road to Laura Stanziola’s Uncanny Artist collage specialty shop. Billy Mavreas explores the fields of textures & plans of resonance of Toronto-based Jacob Whibley. Cory W. Peeke sits down and talks about the macro and the micro with David King. Ric Kasini Kadour explores collage’s role in the darker side of Pop Art at the Whitney Museum in New York. Benoit Depelteau reviews the book Modern Vintage Illustration by Martin Dawber. Paul Bright reviews Romare Bearden: A Black Odyssey at Reynolda House Museum of Art in Winston-Salem, North Carolina. Claudia Eve Beauchesne reviews "Faking It: Manipulated Photography Before Photoshop" at The Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. We go in the studio with Marian Williams. Portfolios from collage artists Berlin, Germany; Salem, Oregon; Halifax, Nova Scotia; London, England; and Los Angeles, California. Issue Four: Evolving Collage Nadine Boughton’s Ravished is on the cover. Editor Benoit Depelteau reflects on the magazine’s first year. Veeranganakumari Solanki profiles the magical realism of Manjunath Kamath. Cory Peeke tells us all about collage on Tumblr. Shane De Lange profiles South African artist Asha Zero. Paul Bright reports on collage at Volta NY and The Armory Show. We review the The Collage Workbook, Sojourner Truth Parsons at Katherine Mulherin Contemporary, and Peter Hutchinson at Freight+Volume Gallery. Nikki Soppelsa shows us her studio. We take a look at portfolios Gloucester, Massachusetts; Etampes, France; Laval, Quebec; Austin, Texas; and Ottawa, Ontario. The Kolaj Year One Collector's Pack includes issues 1-4 of Kolaj. Details: 10″x8″ | saddle stitched | ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

description: COLLAGE & THE ALBUM COVER In the sixth issue of Kolaj Magazine, Lou Beach's Ring Ring, Too Fat Me (The Japanese Corner) is on the cover. David Powell interviews the collage-meister in this issue. Editor Benoit Depelteau talks about collage's role in pop music and the album cover. Cory Peeke and Nick "NickFRESH" Puzo in conversation with Winston Smith. "Collage in the Service of Rebellion or Are We Just In It for the Money?" asks Edvard Derkert. We asked collage artist Laura Tringali Holmes to talk about her experience of being part of a works-on-paper show. Burmese artist San Zaw Htway is profiled by Luigi Galimberti Faussone. Claudia Eve Beauchesne reviews "Cut 'n' Paste: From Architectural Assemblage to Collage City" at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. name: Pastries by Kate Longmaid
description: Set of five greeting cards, blank inside 7"x5" with matching envelopes KATE LONGMAID Vermont painter Kate Longmaid explores the rich terrain of individual identity and what is revealed in the intimate moments of seeing and being seen. “Working in the alla prima tradition, I paint largely from life, seeking to capture a sense of immediacy, freshness, and emotional depth in my portraits,” said Longmaid. “From the privileged position of witnessing the other, I seek to convey the unique presence of each subject as well as our shared humanity.” Known as a portrait artist, Longmaid has developed a reputation as someone who paints the human condition. In recent years, she has added still life to her repertoire. ABOUT KASINI HOUSE ART CARDS Kasini House Art Cards is an experience of contemporary art in greeting card format. All cards are 5”x7”, blank on the inside, and come with a matching envelope. Subjects range from landscape to abstract work to collage.

name: Brayden Shayne's Dirty Pictures, Volume 1
description:
Welcome to Brayden Shayne’s DIRTY PICTURES. 

In Volume 1, they kick off their Salute To Men We Love by featuring Audrey Hepburn on the cover. Brayden Shayne is a queer artists’ collective based in North America. DIRTY PICTURES is a collection of original art and photography, collaged images, and found images that are sometimes manipulated. Pictures are paired with words, which Wikipedia says are the smallest elements that may be uttered in isolation with semantic or pragmatic content with literal or practical meaning. Their goal is for each issue to be a parade of faggotry with a soupcon of pretty things scattered about.

Details: 16 Cards | 5.5"x3.5" | full colour | 2013

name: Brayden Shayne's Dirty Pictures, Volume 2
description:
Welcome to Brayden Shayne’s DIRTY PICTURES. 

In Volume 2, they continue their Salute To Men We Love by featuring Bea Arthur on the cover. Brayden Shayne is a queer artists’ collective based in North America. DIRTY PICTURES is a collection of original art and photography, collaged images, and found images that are sometimes manipulated. Pictures are paired with stories or adages, which Wikipedia says are aphorisms that have gained credibility by virtue of long use. Their goal is for each issue to be a cum-bucket of faggotry with a hump of lovely things mixed in.

Details: 16 Cards | 5.5"x3.5" | full colour | 2013

name: Brayden Shayne's Dirty Pictures, Volume 3
description:
Welcome to Brayden Shayne’s DIRTY PICTURES. 

In Volume 3, they continue their Salute To Men We Love by featuring George Takei on the cover. Brayden Shayne is a queer artists’ collective based in North America. DIRTY PICTURES is a collection of original art and photography, collaged images, and found images that are sometimes manipulated. Pictures are paired with phrases, which Wikipedia says are groups of words that form a constituent and so function as a single unit in the syntax of a sentence. name: I Keep Myself Together by Ric Kasini Kadour
description: “I Keep Myself Together” is a series of 10 photographs that contrast urban isolation and natural beauty. Ric Kasini Kadour is a Montreal-based artist and writer who is active in Vermont's art community. In recent years, Kadour has exhibited work in Montreal, Toronto, Provincetown, and Vermont. His work is in private collections in London (UK), Toronto, Seattle, Provincetown, Washington, DC and New Jersey. He is a contributor to Art New England and other publications. Learn more at his website. Details: Booklet | 5.75″x6″ | Saddle-stitch | 2013 | ISBN 978-1-927587-12-6

name: Kolaj - Issue Five
description: THREADS OF PERCEPTION In the fifth issue of Kolaj Magazine, Allan Bealy's Tie is on the cover. This Brooklyn artist is doing interesting things with the insides of product boxes. Editor Benoit Depelteau gives us his thoughts on that line between collage as fine art and craft collage. Claudia Eve Beauchesne shares a profile of NYC street artist Dain. Ric Kasini Kadour interviews Vermont artist Duncan Johnson who is collaging wood reclaimed from the town dump. Ariane Fairlie reviews Ellen Gallagher's work at Tate Modern in London. We look at new scholarship on the final years of Kurt Schwitters. Cory Peeke reviews the book O! Tricky Cad and Other Jessoterica Nancy Flagg gives us a glimpse at Northern California collagists with a review of a group show in Sacramento Lisa Kehler reviews Greg Lamarche’s "All of the Above" exhibition at Graffiti Gallery in Winnipeg, Manitoba. Elizabeth Hazard reviews tells us about Elektra KB's "There are Women at the Gates Seeking a New World" at BravinLee in New York City. We go inside Ross Carron's studio. We take a look at portfolios from Brooklyn, New York; Barcelona, Spain; Goshen, Connecticut; Montreal, Quebec, Canada; and Houston, Texas. And, as always, there's a new Cut-Out Page. And much much more. Details: 10″x8″ | saddle stitched | ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

name: The Emotional Upholstery Council by Jp King
description: A prescription for avoiding the itch of mosquitoes and fleas. Part department store catalogue, part contest regulations gone awry. The cartography of a Canadiana dystopia where the Horse Oracle sees all. How to relax in difficult postures. Jp King is a writer and relational, investigative publisher from Toronto, whose works explore contemporary mythology, masculinity, garbage, and collective activity. His obsession with paper manifests itself in collage, installation, murals, and multiples. When the timing is right he plays the role of designer, editor, residency coordinator, and conversational facilitator. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini Details: Booklet | 7″x5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2013 | ISBN 978-1-927587-03-4 SUBSCRIBE TO RIBBON PIG A subscription to Ribbon Pig is a great way to get introduced to fresh literary voices and new writers. Subscribe to Ribbon Pig and the next ten editions will be delivered to your mailbox automatically when they are released. New editions are released every four to five weeks.

name: Smile by Jeremy Colangelo
description: A strangely riveting story about a call-center worker that doubles as a kind of manifesto for humanism in the information age. Jeremy Colangelo is a poet and novelist residing in Southern Ontario. His publications include the poetry chapbooks The Limits of My Language and Logology from Grey Borders Books and pieces in several publications in both Canada and the United States. He has a BA in English and History from Brock University. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini Details: Booklet | 7″ x5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2013 | ISBN 978-1-927587-01-0

name: Carl David Ruttan: Torn Passages
description:
A consummate traveler, Carl David Ruttan makes collages with graphic ephemera he finds along the way: Chinese cigarette cartons, Indian candy wrappers, torn bits of music posters from the street. Working in a rented room in Berlin, a youth hostel in Switzerland, on the beach in India, or his apartment in Montreal, Ruttan spreads out the fragments and brings the bits and pieces together in composition. When done, he slides the small 3.5”x2.5” collages into a plastic sleeve. Once home, Ruttan scans them, enlarges the image, and makes a print in edition of three. The final image presents a seamless photographic print that is akin to photomontage.

This catalogue presents the work exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal, January 6-23, 2010. The exhibition explored Ruttan’s collage practice and the relationship between the small collages and large prints of them. The catalogue contains an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour, an interview with the artist, and ten images.

Details: 7.25"x5.25" | 32 pages | 10 images | 
ISBN 978-0-9865298-0-1

name: Kolaj Magazine - Issue Four
description: EVOLVING COLLAGE In the fourth issue of Kolaj Magazine, Nadine Boughton's Ravished is on the cover of Issue 4. Editor Benoit Depelteau reflects on the magazine's first year. Veeranganakumari Solanki profiles the magical realism of Manjunath Kamath. Cory Peeke tells us all about collage on Tumblr. Shane De Lange profiles a South African artist. Paul Bright reports on collage at Volta NY and The Armory Show. We review the The Collage Workbook, Sojourner Truth Parsons at Katherine Mulherin Contemporary, and Peter Hutchinson at Freight+Volume Gallery. Nikki Soppelsa shows us her studio. We take a look at portfolios from Gloucester, Massachusetts; Etampes, France; Laval, Quebec; Austin, Texas; and Ottawa, Ontario. And, as always, there's a new Cut-Out Page. And much much more. Details: 10″x8″ | saddle stitched | ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

name: The North Yorker by Alain Mercieca
description:
The North Yorker is a collection of short stories about Ontario, highways, Montreal, the suburbs, shitty Canadiana and how to embrace it all.  An attempt to bridge humour writing with poetry, and to bring Canadian culture to the fore without the wheat fields and the boring incest, because in the end we’re all stuck in the shopping mall.

“Stellar content... The North Yorker is seemingly the product of a hyperactive imagination run amok, and there's enough crazed, vaguely psychotic creativity here to fill Centrepoint Mall...For reals... this is some messed up shit.  Daddy likes!”
-Cameron Gordon, Broken Pencil magazine

About Alain Mercieca

Alain Mercieca is a writer living in St. Henri, Montreal.  His plays DéPFLIES and CAFé CAFé have garnered acclaim at Theatre 314 and now at Theatre Sainte-Catherine where he is currently the playwright in residence.  His next book The Mild Heroics of Eric is due out in 2013.

DETAILS: The North Yorker | 5.5″ x 8.5″ | Paperback, Perfect | 86 pages | Maison Kasini Books | 2012

ISBN: 978-1-927587-10-2
Release Date: November 15, 2012
Price: $14.95

name: To the Sea
description: To the Sea photography booklet Photographs by Matt Hovey Poem by Matthew Arnold Commentary by Ric Kasini Kadour To The Sea is a 28-page booklet that features photographs by Matt Hovey of nude men playing in the ocean to illustrate Victorian-era poet Matthew Arnold’s “The Forsaken Merman". The resulting juxtaposition is a meditation on man’s role in society and the tensions between obligation and play. Vermont-born Matt Hovey lives in Montreal. In 2011, Maison Kasini published "Berlin to Prague", a folio of photographs and he was featured in the art subscription Papirmasse. His website is www.thisiswhatsthere.com. Ric Kasini Kadour is a writer, gallerist, and artist who lives in Montreal, where he is the co-owner and director of Maison Kasini. His website is www.rickasinikadour.com. Matthew Arnold was a Victorian-era British poet and critic who was viewed as a proto-modernist. He is regarded as one of the era’s greatest poets after Alfred, Lord Tennyson and Robert Browning. Being a long dead Victorian, Arnold does not have a website. Details: 28 page booklet | 5.5" x 5.5" | 16 full colour photographs | saddle-stitched | published by Maison Kasini | 2012

name: Where the Hell Are We
description: This Is What’s There Where The Hell Are We This Is What’s There believes the best representation of a city is the people who live there. They are interested in the places where people live and play: the corner cafes, family markets, off-the-wall bars, people-watching parks, the restaurant nobody knows about and that weird little shop of awesome. We are the experiential, anti-tourist, the home-grown, backpack-toting, back alley explorers. Where The Hell Are We contains eleven stories about some of the most interesting places on the planet that you’ve never heard of in cities that you think you know: Singapore; Madison, Wisconsin; Istanbul; St. Thomas; Rome; Montreal; London; New Orleans; Varna, Bulgaria; Florence; Marrakech; Paris; Prague; Berlin; Malta; and Venice, Italy Details: 81 page book | 5.5″ x 5.5″ | 20 full colour photograph illustrations | perfect-bound | ISBN 978-0-9880233-0-7 | 2012

name: I Am My Own Betrayal by Guillaume Morissette
description: I Am My Own Betrayal is a bizarrely comic, profoundly modern, honest, sad, surprising collection of stories and poems. It explores subjects such as anxiety, email relationships, owl people, awkwardness, social networks, humiliations, shortcomings, groundhogs, terrible personal decisions, videogames, coping, girly arms and cat seizures. A highly imaginative and refreshing literary debut. ‘One of our favorite writers,’ -Kirsten McCrea, Papirmasse ‘A unique voice, with striking details,’ -Josip Novakovich, author of Three Deaths ‘Depressingly hopeful, like looking at yourself naked in the mirror,’ -Lizy Mostowski, Soliloquies About Guillaume Morissette I Am My Own Betrayal is Guillaume Morissette’s debut collection of stories and poems. His writing has appeared both online and in print, in publications like Maisonneuve Magazine, carte-blanche, Metazen, Papirmasse, The Void Magazine, Lemonhoud and Poetry’s Own. He is a contributor to HTMLGiant, the internet literature magazine blog of the future. He lives in Montreal where he studies creative writing at Concordia University and served as the editor of Ribbon Pig in 2012. DETAILS: I Am My Own Betrayal | 5.5″ x 8.5″ | Paperback, Perfect | 102 pages | Maison Kasini Books | 2012 ISBN: 978-0-9878094-9-0 Release Date: May 18, 2012 Price: $14.95

name: Curiosa by Matt Hovey and writing by Stephen Schaub (Papirmasse #15)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 15 features photography by Matt Hovey, Curiosa, and the essay, "Is Photography Dead? No, honey, it's just sleeping" by Stephen Schaub. Matt Hovey is a modern day flâneur. He commits acts of peripatetic strolling to experience the places he visits. The act of taking photographs is as much a means of documenting his travels as it is a way of experiencing a place. To stop and compose a shot, to look at a scene and consider the objects in it and the objects around it and the light and air, and to view the image through a lens–these actions lead to a greater sense of looking and experiencing. The photograph that comes of it is an artifact of the experience and a living, breathing piece of art the viewer can use to engage the place from which it came. Vermont born and raised, Matt is a consummate traveller. He is the creator of This Is What’s There, an ongoing photography project that seeks to capture and share the everyday of far away. Curiosa is a photo taken in Madrid, Spain as part of series exploring the poster culture of various cities. Stephen Schaub is recognized in the photographic industry as an expert and innovator of hybrid shooting and progressive printing techniques, both digital and analog. His artwork has been featured in numerous print publications as well as many online publications. A graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, he is the author of two collections of photographs as well as co-author of a book on the state of contemporary photographic practice. He lives in Vermont. Online, Stephen is the leader of the Figital Revolution, whose mission is to challenge the assumption that digital and analog photography (film) must exist in isolation and opposition from each other. Find out more at www.stephenschaub.com Details: 12"x8.25" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: from How the Alphabet Was Made by rob mclennan
description: rob mclennan’s poems resonate as being an experiment in language, gently leading the reader through a linguistic kaleidoscope of perishing moments; lush, explorative and haunting. rob mclennan is the author of more than twenty trade books of poetry, fiction and non-fiction. An editor and publisher, he runs above/ground press, Chaudiere Books, The Garneau Review, seventeen seconds: a journal of poetry and poetics and the Ottawa poetry pdf annual ottawater. He spent the 2007-2008 academic year in Edmonton as writer-in-residence at the University of Alberta, and regularly posts reviews, essays, interviews and other notices at www.robmclennan.blogspot.com Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini. Details: Single-Fold Card | 7″ x5″ | 2013 | ISBN 978-1-927587-02-7

name: 4 Series by Rebecca Adams and 4 Poems by Ariel Gordon (Papirmasse #27)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse 27 is a small accordion folded booklet with art on one side and writing on the other! The front is 4 series of film stills by Providence, Rhode Island painter Rebecca Adams. The back is 4 poems by Ariel Gordon. Rebecca Adams specializes in black and white painting, obsessively collecting, organizing, and cataloging old film stills and vintage stock photography. Her work explores different forms of repetition, while retaining one iconic object that relates each “character” within the series. She lives and works in Providence, Rhode Island, where she obtained a BFA in photography from RISD. See more at www.rebeccamadams.com. Ariel Gordon is a Winnipeg-based writer. Her first full-length collection, Hump (Palimpsest Press) was shaped by pregnancy and mothering. Ariel was the 2010 recipient of the John Hirsch award for most promising Manitoba writer and the 2011 Aqua Books Lansdowne Prize for Poetry. Most recently, she collaborated with designer Julia Michaud on the disaster DIY chapbook How to Prepare for Flooding (JackPine Press). When not being bookish, Ariel likes tromping through the woods and taking macro-photographs of mushrooms. See more at www.janedayreader.blogspot.com. Details: 7"x5" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This accordion booklet ships folded.

name: Spirits by Aman and Howl!, Wolf! by Ellie Anglin (Papirmasse #26)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse 26 is a mash-up of art and poetry from Hungary and Toronto, respectively. Side 1 features a fantastic illustration by Aman (David Szebenyi). Flip it over to read the double poem ‘Howl!’, ‘Wolf!’ by Ellie Anglin. David Szebenyi aka Aman is a young artist living in Budapest, Hungary. He currently works as a freelance graphic designer and studies art. Living on the border between city and nature, he is inspired by both atmospheres and creates work through a mixture of digital and traditional methods. When he was 14, he was inspired by street-art and graffiti artists, and this formed his unique world of thinking and drawing. Being a VJ and a DJ as well, he is connected to music and art on more levels, the skills highly affecting each other, resulting usually in something powerful. See more at www.a-man.hu Ellie Anglin is a Toronto-based writer of prose, poetry and creative non-fiction as well as a multi-media visual artist working mostly in collage. She grew up in Waterloo, Ontario, where she received her BA in English Literature. She regularly self-publishes her writing and art work; watch out for the upcoming Tender Buttons, which is generously supported by the Toronto Arts Council. More information about her art and writing can be found at www.ellieanglin.blogspot.com, and her writing about the cats of her neighbourhood can be found at www.catsofparkdale.blogspot.com Details: 10.5"x8.5" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: Miracle & Nebraska by Steph Wong Ken
description: Two stories that excavate the finite nature of miraculous bodies. Profane and profound, Miracle & Nebraska sits somewhere between the explosion of light from the Delta II space disaster and the caustic lemon perfume of a hospital. Steph Wong Ken is a writer and editor based in Calgary, Alberta. She graduated from the Creative Writing program at Concordia University in 2010 and received a fellowship to the Summer Literary Seminars 2011. Her work has appeared in Soliloquies and Headlight Anthology. She blogs at stephwongken.blogspot.com. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini. Details: Booklet | 7″ x5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2013 | ISBN 978-1-927587-00-3

description: Six Cans of Authentic Contemporary Art: Red, Green, Blue, Yellow, Orange, & Purple by Ric Kasini Kadour set of 6 cans each 3.5” tall x 2.5” diameter 11.7oz edition of 50 signed & numbered 2013

name: Art by Victoria Wiercinski and Text by Jacob Wren (Papirmasse #24)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 24 features a Risograph print by Victoria Wiercinsky and Insincere YouTube Auteur by Jacob Wren. Victoria Wiercinski has a single mission as an artist: to make the world a more beautiful place. With a penchant for textiles and intricate patterns combined with the firm belief that basic living items can (and should) be beautiful, she wields pen, paintbrush and craft techniques toward any project that comes her way. Always interested in new techniques, Victoria applies her drawings to textiles, clothing, letterpressed items, ceramics, stationery and more. She is an avid maker of products, and runs her one-woman craft and design empire, Veekee Workshop, from the cozy Canadian prairie city of Edmonton, Alberta. She also co-organises the Royal Bison Craft and Art Fair, a semi-annual curated showcase of the best Edmonton’s art scene has to offer. Victoria graduated from the University of Alberta with a Bachelor of Design and extended her knowledge with textiles courses at NSCAD. She is a fan of learning about new techniques from books in the library and a whole bunch of trial and error. Jacob Wren is a writer and maker of eccentric performances. His books include Unrehearsed Beauty, Families Are Formed Through Copulation, Revenge Fantasies of the Politically Dispossessed and the forthcoming novel Polyamorous Love Song. As co-artistic director of the Montreal-based interdisciplinary group PME-ART he tours internationally with alarming frequency. He frequently writes about contemporary art. Insincere YouTube Auteur first appeared online in the journal Dragnet. Details: 13"x10" | Risograph print on tan kraft paper | 2011 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: Uptown/Downtown by Harley Smart and Dust by Lisa Moore (Papirmasse #25)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse 25 features the work of digital-glitch-landscape painter Harley Smart of New York City and gritty realist writer Lisa More of Winnipeg. Using motion activated data projection on traditionally painted supports, Harley Smart’s work explores the interrupted image and fragmented figuration in post-digital painting while challenging viewer interaction with the traditional painted portrait. He is the co-founder of Anteism Publishing and the publication manager at The Hole NYC. He currently lives and works in New York. See more at www.finewest.ca Lisa More grew up in a bush town in northern Alberta, where her father sold lumber to people surrounded by trees. She spent her school years hiding in the library and skipping school to watch music videos. She holds a degree in Comparative Literature and works as a policy advisor and speechwriter in Winnipeg, Manitoba. Lisa writes in pursuit of that one good line, and is even happier if she can set it to music. She plays lead guitar in Winnipeg country punk trio The Bushtits. She also performs with Winnipeg outlaw country outfit Cheering for the Bad Guy and appears on their album To the Last Drop. Details: 11.5"x8.5" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: Tiki Buddah Cow
description: From the series "My Junk Taste Like Flowers": colour instant photographs about objects and joy. The artist made sculptures with his junk that were then venerated with flowers. Ric Kasini Kadour explains, "Arranging my junk was like restacking and reordering memories. The whole was other than the sum of its parts." Kadour documented each of these sculptures using a Polaroid 360 Land Camera and Fujifilm FP-100c to make a colour instant photograph in editions of three, except for the titular piece, My Junk Taste Like Flowers, which is an edition of 100 and released as FRESH NUMBER 2. Details 4.25” x 3.25” colour instant photograph 2013 8”x10” frame edition of 3

name: Art and Writing by Jp King (Papirmasse #14)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 14 features My Secret Trombone Song and "The Suffering of Food", both by Jp King. Jp King was born in Toronto in 1985. He currently lives and writes in Montreal. His books and prints have been shown in Halifax, Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal, Minnesota, and Stockholm. His book of poetry and illustration We Will Be Fish (in which the illustration on Side 2 first appeared) was published by PistolPress in 2008. A 27-foot-long book of collaged images and poetic text fragments is forthcoming with Anteism. He currently works as production manager of an eco-friendly print shop by day, and as Paper Pusher by night. Paper Pusher is Jp’s latest publishing endeavour, an exciting collection of experimental publishing projects, public art interventions, and collaborations with numerous authors and artists. Details: 18"x12" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: Beach by Genevieve Simms and Your Head by Matt Prins (Papirmasse #32)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse headed to the Canadian prairies with issue 32, bringing you art and writing from two Edmontonians. Genevieve Simms and Matt Prins have each made a name for themselves; Genevieve as an award-winning illustrator and co-creator of International Beauty Saloon (one of our favourite zines and highly coveted for its excellent content and beautiful screen printed covers), and Matt as a writer and the creator of Instant Books Are Your Future, a website and innovative publishing project that scans small books specially made in a clever format. Of the 300 documented on his website so far over half come from contributors around the world. Genevieve Simms is a Canadian illustrator based in Edmonton, AB. After graduating from the Alberta College of Art and Design in 2006 she attended a guest study program at the School of Visual Arts, New York. Since settling in Edmonton in 2007 Genevieve has worked on editorial illustration assignments for a variety of clients and self-published the serial zine International Beauty Saloon with Josh Holinaty. Genevieve’s illustration work has been recognized by The Art Director’s Club of New York, American Illustration, The Society of Illustrators, and Communication Arts. In 2011 she was awarded Gold for Spot Illustration at The National Magazine Awards in Toronto. Recently, Genevieve has completed a diploma in Architectural Technology at NAIT. See more at www.genevievesimms.ca Matt Prins is an Edmonton-based writer who has published and exhibited fiction, non-fiction, journalism, poetry, photography and illustration around the world. His work has appeared in publications such as Colors Magazine, the Learning to Love You More book, V, and fancy things like this. His blog – Instant Books Are Your Future – has close to 300 mini-zines scanned in for your pleasure. Nearly a third of these come from guest contributors from around the world. Matt is currently in the midst of making a pirate radio station for Edmonton’s temporary art exhibit – Dirt City Dream City – and in the past has exhibited projects in Vienna’s MAK, Paris’ Pompidou, Milan’s Triennale, and Eindhoven’s MU. A former Creative Writing resident at Fabrica in Treviso Italy, and grad of Vancouver Film School, Matt has lived in many different neighborhoods in many different cities in many different countries and carries a piece of each of those living quarters with him. (Quickly: big fan of Nintendo, fart jokes, Green Onion Cakes, cartoons, kissing.) See more at www.instantbooks.wordpress.com Details: 12"x8.25" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: How to Remain Celibate by Celia Spenard-Ko
description: How to Remain Celibate is a delightful exploration of what it means to be celibate and a powerful reminder that even words on their own can be filled with a certain kind of eroticism. Celia Spenard-Ko is a Montreal writer, photographer and filmmaker. Torn between three passions, she chose to give up something of lesser importance: sleep. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini Details: Single-Fold Card | 2012 | ISBN 978-1-927587-04-1

name: Pond by Isabel M. Martinez and Sal Salim and Me by Omar Mouallem (Papirmasse #35)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse #35 is all about perception. Isabel M. Martínez spent her formative years in Santiago de Chile and holds a BFA from Universidad Católica de Chile and an MFA from the University of Guelph. She has exhibited internationally in galleries and at events such as CONTACT Photography Festival, Magenta’s Flash Forward, and FotoAmérica Bienal de Fotografía. Her work has been featured in Fast Company, Booooooom, and Juxtapoz, among others. She lives and works in Toronto. See more at www.immartinez.com The photographs in "Quantum Blink" are composed of two exposures taken instants apart. The striped pattern is the result of masks placed in-camera, allowing the two images to blend together and at the same time keep them from fully fusing onto one another. Each photograph in the series holds a brief sense of continuity, almost like an animation, slightly cinematographic; however, though they provide a notion of movement and progression, their beginning and end is ambiguous and indistinguishable. Omar Mouallem is an Edmonton-based writer who has contributed to publications such as the Globe and Mail, Eighteen Bridges, and enRoute. For his nonfiction he has received numerous distinctions, including from the National Magazine Awards and Sex-Positive Journalism Awards, but he’s only just begun his foray into fiction. He sharpens his storytelling at Edmonton Story Slam competitions, where in fact his Papirmasse story won the 2012 Grand Slam. His debut album as rapper AOK (Assault Of Knowledge), If You Don’t Buy This CD the Terrorists Win, received international acclaim from music critics, who praised it for its edge and wit. His second book and album, Q Without U, combined children’s literature with adult-oriented hip hop. www.assaultofknowledge.com / @omar_aok Details: 9"x9" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat.

name: Ode to Common Things
description: From the series "My Junk Taste Like Flowers": colour instant photographs about objects and joy. The artist made sculptures with his junk that were then venerated with flowers. Ric Kasini Kadour explains, "Arranging my junk was like restacking and reordering memories. The whole was other than the sum of its parts." Kadour documented each of these sculptures using a Polaroid 360 Land Camera and Fujifilm FP-100c to make a colour instant photograph in editions of three, except for the titular piece, My Junk Taste Like Flowers, which is an edition of 100 and released as FRESH NUMBER 2. Details 4.25” x 3.25” colour instant photograph 2013 8”x10” frame edition of 3

name: Kolaj Magazine - Issue Three
description: FRAGMENTS AND IDEAS? In the third issue of Kolaj Magazine, Cory Peeke talks to David King & Billy Mavreas talks to Jacob Whibley. We toast Maggie Groat winning the ABOM award. We visit an uncanny collage shop in Santa Fe, New Mexico. We find collage at Sinister Pop at the Whitney Museum. Paul Bright goes on Romare Bearden’s Black Odyssey. We turn the pages of Modern Vintage. We visit Marian Williams in her studio. We present artist portfolios from artists in Canada, Germany, the United Kingdom and the USA. And much much more. Details: 10″x8″ | saddle stitched | ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

name: Luchadorable by Kirsten McCrea and excerpts from after party by Kerri Flannigan (Papirmasse #33)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse #33: Artist Kirsten McCrea and writer Kerri Flannigan have teamed up to bring us a hilarious and introspective issue about coming-of-age, self-consciousness, and finding ones place in the world. Kirsten McCrea is a Canadian artist whose work explores issues of cultural memory, looking at pop vs. underground culture, the media, and popular mythologies. Primarily a painter, she is also the founder and editor of Papirmasse. Her paintings have exhibited nationally and her patterned drawings can be found on notebooks and apparel in stores around the world. When not working on her own she collaborates with the drawing initiative En Masse, whose work was recently shown in the form of a massive installation in the Musée des Beaux Arts in Montreal. See more at www.hellokirsten.com About the art: Featuring a male figure and someone without an ideal body (by North American pop-cultural standards), Luchadorable aims to turn the notion of the “pin-up” on its head. Lucha Libre wrestlers bear more resemblance to the classic female pin-up than at first meets the eye: utilizing idealized representations of masculinity in their performances and donning spectacular costumes, it can be said that they are not dissimilar from the stereotypical female pin-up, who represents an idealized vision of femininity in her high-heels, tight-binding corsets, and dramatic make-up. This “pin-up” is someone who by his profession is centre of attention, but in the role of sex symbol his bravado gives way to self-consciousness. It’s a feeling that we probably all know too well. Details: 17.5"x11.5" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships in a tube.

name: Subscription to Ribbon Pig
description: Ribbon Pig is a project about curating literature. We publish booklets and pamphlets that present contemporary writing. Our website presents interviews with contributors as well as other pieces of writing. We do this to explore ideas about contemporary culture, draw connections between literature and art, and to promote the idea that you are what you read. Our goal is to build a community of people who would enjoy these objects and share our interests. Ribbon Pig (established in 2011, based in Montreal) is a project of Maison Kasini. A subscription to Ribbon Pig is a great way to get introduced to fresh literary voices and new writers. Subscribe to Ribbon Pig and the next ten editions will be delivered to your mailbox automatically when they are released. New editions are released every four to five weeks.

name: The Off-Season by Drew Nelles
description: The Off-Season by Drew Nelles is an eerily insightful piece that gracefully balances two character's perspectives while subtly revealing a strange friendship struck between two very different people. Drew Nelles is the editor-in-chief of Maisonneuve Magazine and a Montreal-based writer. He’s been published in the Walrus, Reader’s Digest, This Magazine, the Montreal Mirror, BULLETT, the Toronto Standard and Canadian Dimension. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini. Details: Booklet | 7″ x5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2012 | ISBN 978-1-927587-09-6

name: Harbinger by Carl David Ruttan (Papirmasse #28)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Side 1 of Papirmasse 28 features Harbinger, a small collage in its entirety. Side 2 zooms in on the original, bringing it to life in a new way. It’s an unusual format from us, but we hope that you enjoy this take on an artist who is using collage in a new and unusual way. Carl David Ruttan is a collage artist who works in a very special way, completing small originals out of paper ephemera collected in city streets around the world, scanning them at an extremely high-resolution, and then making a single huge print of each collage image. Framed together, the original and the print form a single piece that at once reference and enhance each other. The resulting print is a sight to behold: a fantastic magnifying glass that illuminates incredible details invisible to the naked eye in the original. The intricate patterning of money becomes richly detailed in a way you can never appreciate when it’s in your hands, the paper “hairs” from a torn sheet of cardboard are suddenly as beautiful and wispy as a field of grass, and the slight misalignment of printed packaging forms a beautiful constellation of dots. Details: 6"x12" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat.

name: Papirmasse 2011-Complete Set
description: Papirmasse is a magazine, original artwork, and social experiment all rolled into one. We want everyone to have art – real art! Not the fake paintings sold at department stores or the same tired old posters every college student has. No! We want images to travel and people to get excited about seeing. Down with blank walls; Up with Affordable Art! Papirmasse is art by subscription. Each month, a new issue is sent to subscribers. The 2011 Folio contains 22 prints featuring work from artists and writers from around the world, from Costa Rica to France, all over Canada and New York! Sizes range from 5"x7" to 12"x18". Each print has art on the front and writing on the back. Details: Folio measuring 12.5″x9.5″ containing 22 archival prints on paper in sizes ranging from 5″ x 7″ to 12″ x 18″ | Printed in Montreal | 2011

name: David Orfé: Maori Victorians
description: booklet In his series, “Maori Victorians”, French artist David Orfé presents a series of eight small portraits and one large painting that feature figures marked with the facial hair and dress of Victorians and geometric patterns that echo the tā moko of the Maori people. The result is a curious body of work: What is the significance to a North American viewer of a 21st century French artist painting 19th century men and women with the primitive markings reminiscent of the aboriginal people of New Zealand? Orfé was born and raised in the northern French city of Lille. After his studies, he began traveling. He spent six months in Dublin, Ireland. He traveled all 25,760 kilometres of the Australian coast. During Orfé’s 15-month sojourn in New Zealand, he traveled around the islands and made his way by doing seasonal work: working in the wine industry, picking fruit and pruning vines. Orfé has an appreciation of and natural curiosity about other cultures which traveling allows him to explore. Details: ISBN 978-0-9865298-8-7 Publisher: Maison Kasini Canada | 2011 Size: 7.5″x5.25″ Binding: saddle-stitched paperback 24 pages 12 images Publication ©2011 Maison Kasini Canada Images ©2011 David Orfé Book Design by Ric Kasini Kadour

Details 4.25” x 3.25” colour instant photograph 2013 8”x10” frame edition of 3

name: Kolaj Magazine - Issue Two
description: IS THIS COLLAGE? In the second issue of Kolaj Magazine, Kolaj editor Benoit Depelteau asks, “Is this collage?”, Ric Kasini Kadour tells how Venezuelan collage artist Alejandro Otero brought modernity to his country. News & Notes gives updates on five collage shows in the USA and Canada. Kolaj editor Benoit Depelteau investigates collage as process with artist Emmanuel Laflamme. Billy Mavreas’ “Collage Today & Everyday” explores collage culture. Cory W. Peeke talks with four collage artists about their love of vintage materials. Edvard Derkert comments on urban postering as an act of collage. Ariane Fairlie presents an artist profile of Jessica Korderas, who makes collages in resin. Müge Akçakoca reviews “Cut & Paste” at Gallery Ilayda in Istanbul, Turkey. Cory W. Peeke reviews the artist catalogue Implications: John Hundt. Ric Kasini Kadour reviews Matthew Cusick’s “The Mind Is Its Own Place” at the Pavel Zoubok Gallery. Carolina Cochron shows us her studio. Portfolios from collage artists: Sejma Prodanovic, Belgrade, Serbia; Marty Gordon, Seattle, Washington, USA; Caro-Ma, Paris, France; Kieran Sperring, Shropshire, England, United Kingdom; Virginia Fleck, Austin, Texas, USA and the latest Cut-Out Page! Details: 10″x8″ | saddle stitched | 70 full colour pages ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

name: Art and Writiing by Jp King (Papirmasse #36)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 36 is a double-issue, featuring the art and writing of Toronto-based creative Jp King. Side 1 features the collage How Do My Secrets Feel In Your Ear by Jp King, and side 2 features a letter from the fictional Nomadic Residency Council, inviting the reader to rethink the context in which they undertake a creative act. Jp King’s work explores contemporary mythology, masculinity, garbage, and collective activity. His obsession with paper manifests itself in collage, installation, murals, and multiples. When the timing is right he plays the role of editor, residency coordinator, and conversational facilitator. He is the author of the book We Will Be Fish and his work has appeared in numerous small press publications and magazines. He runs Paper Pusher, a small Risograph publishing operation. See more at www.jpking.ca Playing off the official rhetoric and language of granting agencies & residencies, The Nomadic Residency Council is an invitation to rethink creative space and consider any place an artist’s residency and any moment a prime time to declare oneself an artist-in-residence. This text was written at a 24-hour publications residency with Eva Weinmayr and Shannon Gerrard at OCAD U. The collage on the reverse was created in a more formal residency setting, while Jp King was Artist-In-Residence at the Klondike Institute of Arts and Culture, in Dawson City, Yukon. Details: 12"x9" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat.

name: Hot Topic: Portraits of 20th Century Feminists by Kirsten McCrea
description: Maison Kasini announces the publication of Hot Topic: Portraits of 20th Century Feminists by Kirsten McCrea. Hot Topic is a song from the feminist electroclash trio Le Tigre. It was released in 1999 by Mr. Lady Records on Le Tigre’s self-titled debut album. Le Tigre at the time consisted of Kathleen Hanna, Johanna Fateman, and Sadie Benning. Benning was later replaced by JD Samson. The lyrics include the names of fifty-seven feminist icons. Between 2006 and 2008, Montreal-based artist Kirsten McCrea painted a portrait of every single person named in the Le Tigre song plus the band members. The collection of sixty paintings makes up the “Hot Topic” series which was on view at Galerie Maison Kasini August 3 to September 10th, 2011. About Kirsten McCrea Kirsten McCrea is a Montreal-based artist whose work explores issues of cultural memory, looking at pop vs. underground culture, the media, and popular mythologies. Known for her bright colours and figurative subject matter, Kirsten is quickly establishing herself as a prominent emerging Canadian artist. Primarily a painter, she is also the founder and editor of Papirmasse, an affordable art subscription. Her paintings have been exhibited nationally, and her work has been reviewed in The Walrus, Book By Its Cover, and The Montreal Gazette, amongst others. She has illustrated for the Polaris Music Prize, the Under Pressure Graffiti festival, & Poetry Magazine. Papirmasse was nominated for an Expozine Small Press Award in 2010. Kirsten says about her “Hot Topic” paintings: “In a world that celebrates manufactured pop stars but forgets the names of suffragists, I wanted to find a way to solidify the memory of the underground superstars whose creativity and ideas have made such a difference to feminists of my generation, I wanted to use the portrait for its ability to announce importance and greatness, without upholding the tired ideals of the brave and solitary hero or genius. Presented on the wall in a grid, the works no longer stand as individual portraits and instead form a pastiche that is indicative of the interconnectivity and community so integral to feminist culture.” About the Catalogue The catalogue presents the work exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal, August 3 to September 10, 2011. (EXHIBITION DETAILS HERE) The catalogue contains full-colour images of each of the paintings with explanatory text by Beckie Jones. Publication ©2011 Maison Kasini Canada Images ©2011 Kirsten McCrea Text ©2011 Kirsten McCrea & Beckie Jones Book Design by Ric Kasini Kadour Details: 8.75″x8.25″ | 66 pages | 60 full colour images | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-9-4 | 2011 | $24.95 Special Launch Price $20.00

name: Television by Kirsten McCrea & 5 stories by Johhny Forever (Papirmasse #18)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 18 features Television by Kirsten McCrea and five stories by Johnny Forever. Kirsten McCrea is an Edmonton-born, Montreal-based artist whose work explores issues of cultural memory, looking at pop vs. underground culture, the media, and popular mythologies. Primarily a painter, she is also the founder and editor of Papirmasse. Her paintings have been exhibited internationally, and her work has been reviewed by The Walrus, Book By Its Cover, and The Montreal Gazette, amongst others. She has illustrated for the Polaris Music Prize, the Under Pressure Graffiti festival, and Poetry Magazine, and is a member of the celebrated collaborative painting crew En Masse. For more visit www.hellokirsten.com Television is about summoning forgotten technology from the trashbin of history to speak to us once more. Johnny Forever was born in southern Poland a few years before the Wall fell. They spent the sunny days of their first November bundled up in a wicker pram parked outside of a tenement block in Nowa Huta, their mother occasionally looking out at them through the window. This brisk alone time was part of the tried and true process of hardening that all Nowa Huta babies go through one way or another. So Forever learned to love to cold and came to settle in Montreal many years later. Details: 11"x17" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping : This print ships in a tube

name: Berlin to Prague folio
description:
"Berlin to Prague"
folio of 16 photographs by Matt Hovey

In "Berlin to Prague", Hovey presents a series of photographs taken while on a train from Berlin as it travels along the Elbe River, passing through Saxony via Dresden and through the cities of Wehlen and Pirna in “Saxon Switzerland” before crossing into the Czech Republic.

Hovey writes about "Berlin to Prague", “The romantic promise of the train ride--lush riverside landscapes dotted with Gothic castles--is answered with reality: the backyards of poor and middle-class Germans who happen to live by train tracks. My intention in showing these images is to underscore the reality and ultimately celebrate it.”

Details: 7"x 5" | Folio of 16 images on archival paper in an aluminum box | Edition of 50 | 2011

name: Feathers by Sarah Burwash and 3 poems by Megan MacKay (Papirmasse #31)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse #31: Artist Sarah Burwash's (lately of Halifax but most recently of Lunenburg, NS) work features delicate watercolours, depicting intermingling scenes of wildlife and domesticity. Writer/artist Megan MacKay‘s poetry is a good match with its subtle depictions of forlorn relationships. Sarah Burwash graduated from UBC Okanagan in 2009 with a BFA, spending a semester abroad in Hamburg, Germany at the Hamburg University of Applied Sciences. Working in a variety of media from collage and watercolour to video and ceramics, Sarah’s work most often takes form in narrative drawings and installation. Her work is included in private and public collections and has been shown in Canada, the United States and Europe. She has participated in residencies in British Columbia, Ontario, Nova Scotia and Colorado and is Yukon-bound next to attend the KIAC residency. Sarah recently had a solo exhibition at the Ross Creek Centre for the Arts and completed her first animation through The Centre for Art Tapes Media Arts Scholarship program in Halifax where she currently resides, working full time as an artist and freelance illustrator. See more at www.sarahburwash.com When Megan MacKay moved to Fredericton, New Brunswick six years ago, she intended to become a journalist. Instead, she grew into a poet, a playwright, and performance artist. Although she finds herself working in an art gallery instead of a press gallery, the journalistic principles of presenting an honest view of the world have bled into her creative work. Her work of late has focused on the idea of being far from “home” in a traditional sense– be it in a person, or an actual physical location– and finding “home” in non-traditional places. She intends to relocate to Vancouver in the fall to study Creative Writing. Her most recent play, Road Dogs, won a place in the 2012 NotaBle Acts Theatre Festival. Details: 12"x9" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat.

name: Monastiraki--This Is What's There Greeting Card Pack
description: Monastiraki This Is What's There Pack of Greeting Cards A collection of 10 GREETING CARDS photography by Matt Hovey This Is What’s There visits Monastiraki in Montreal. Since 1998, this mutable space has been reinventing itself, moving from "straight-up" antique shop to kitsch haven and underground comix community hub. Today, Monastiraki sports an art gallery and hosts openings, book launches, and micro-concerts. They support a myriad of local and international artists, carry small press and 'zines, overflow with paper ephemera, have a fitful relationship with antiques and collectibles....and are a magical place sure to enchant the curious. This Is What’s There is an ongoing photography project by Hovey that seeks to capture and share the everyday of far away. In this series: Monastiraki, Montreal Flat File Hamilton zines Magazines & Records Tracks Go You L’il Books Crochet Drawers Kasini House Art Cards showcases the work of contemporary artists on blank 5"x7" greeting cards. The title, dimensions, materials and year of the work presented on the front of each card is printed on the back, along with a short statement by the artist. Subjects range from landscape to abstract work to collage. Size: 5 inches by 7 inches Front: Full color image Inside: Blank Back: Text with information about the artist and the artwork Each card includes a matching white envelope and comes in a clear, resealable polypropylene protective bag. More info at Kasini House Art Cards website.

name: Fantastic Plastic by Chloe Beaulac and writing by Dean Garlick (Papirmasse #19)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 19 features Fantastic Plastic 1 and 2 by Chloe Beaulac and an excerpt of "The Visitor" by Dean Garlick. Papirmasse Issue 19 is our very first double-issue: two prints by Montreal artist Chloé Beaulac that form a beautiful and eerie landscape diptych. Chloé Beaulac is from Mississauga, Ontario. She currently lives and works in Montreal, where she obtained a BFA with a minor in Print Media from Concordia University. Her work is a combination of painting, drawing and printmaking. She is also interested in installation and integrating sculptural aspects in her research. Her present work focuses on dreamscapes inspired by her travels throughout Quebec. Chloé has won the CUAA Purchase Prize award and has been nominated as a finalist for the Prix Albert Dumouchel. Her work is found in several notable collections in Canada and Europe. On side 2 are excerpts from Dean Garlick’s forthcoming novella "The Visitor". Dean Garlick is a fiction writer and educator living in Montreal. His debut novel "The Fish" was published by Anteism Press with illustrations by Victoria, B.C. artist Eric Volet. Dean is excited about the possibilities presented by illustrated fiction, both as a means of collaboratively exploring multiple modes of narrative and of representing the experience of reading as a creative act. Printed in this issue of Papirmasse are excerpts from The Visitor, a story about a young woman who gets exactly what she wishes for thanks to what may or may not be a multidimensional parrot. Details: 8"x10" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping: This print ships flat

name: This Is What's There Greeting Card Pack
description: A collection of 10 Greeting Cards featuring photography by Matt Hovey. This Is What’s There is an ongoing photography project by Hovey that seeks to capture and share the everyday of far away. This Is Our Vision: We believe the monuments of a place are the people who live there. We are interested in the the back alleys, corner cafes, family markets and street vendors. The vacant and crumbling building is a story. We want to see photographs that tell us how you live and where you go. We have nothing against the Eiffel Tower, but we are more interested in the graffiti tag on the north west foot than the tip preening over the city. More information at ThisIsWhatsThere.com In this series: I Forget What I Wanted to Say, Vienna The Girl & The Lion, London Posters, Berlin Butts, Berlin Happy Street Art, Berlin Curiosa, Madrid Steps, Montreal Happy Rooster, Montreal Wedgie, London Lunch, Dublin Kasini House Art Cards showcases the work of contemporary artists on blank 5"x7" greeting cards. Subjects range from landscape to abstract work to collage. Size: 5 inches by 7 inches Front: Full color image Inside: Blank Back: Text with information about the artist and the artwork Each card includes a matching white envelope and comes in a clear, resealable polypropylene protective bag. More info at Kasini House Art Cards website.

name: Eco-Friendly Jet Engine by Px(c) and writing by Christopher Olson (Papirmasse #20)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 20 brings together the work of Québecois artists Px(c) and Christopher Olson. The issue features 3 cascading images from Px(c)’s series Eco-Friendly Jet Engine, and is accordion-folded so that you can show off either just one or all three, depending on your taste. Side 2 features a short story about a man who changes everything. Side 1: Eco-Friendly Jet Engine by Px(c) Px(c) is the corporate alter-ego of Montreal artist Ben Depelteau. It first appeared in the 1999 painting You never know when you’ll need Px(c), as a car parts brand name. Px(c) has been known, over the years, to mimic advertising strategies to sell dysfunctional products and ideas to people. Its catalogue includes car parts, eyes, fingers, tongues, sunglasses, do-it-yourself art, concepts for gallery art, mouse traps, packages and some collages and prints. By presenting himself as the corporate entity, Px(c), Depelteau makes a cultural statement about the dominance of commercial culture in everyday life. His work is a hybrid of American and British Pop Art. Find him online at www.the-px-corporation.deviantart.com Christopher Olson is a writer and artist who is frequently mistaken for Christopher Olsen, who is neither an artist nor an actual person, although he often boasts credit for Christopher Olson’s work. He was born in 1986, coinciding with the release of some of his favourite movies, such as Aliens, David Cronenberg’s The Fly, Labyrinth, Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home, but also Howard the Duck. He is currently studying at Concordia University for a degree in English, although this may change as English is kind of hard. He writes and illustrates Tremendous Tales, a quarterly anthology of microfiction. You can visit www.tremendoustales.com if you like what you see here. Details: 9"x18" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping: This print ships flat
