name: Winners by Josh Holinaty and Just What I Was There For by S. Kennedy Sobol (Papirmaase #29)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Papirmasse 29 features the weird line drawings of Prairie artist Josh Holinaty and a short story about birds by S. Kennedy Sobol. Josh Holinaty is an illustrator, visual artist, and musician based out of Edmonton, Alberta. A graduate of the Alberta College of Art & Design and attendee of the New York Studio Program, he has worked for clients such as The Globe and Mail, Maisonneuve, Wired, and OWL magazine, to name a few. In 2010 he completed the mural Transition, a collaboration with artist Luke Ramsey, which received an Edmonton Urban Design Award in Excellence in 2011. If he had to pick a favourite thing to make he would definitely choose posters for rock shows. He thinks art shouldn’t be too serious, nor should it be too pricey. See more at www.holinaty.com S. Kennedy Sobol lives in Toronto, Ontario, where she works as a Technical Writer. She attended the Concordia University Creative Writing program, where she received the Irving Layton Award for Poetry. Her story “Some Light Down” was nominated for the Journey Prize and was included in The Journey Prize Stories 20. See more at www.skennedysobol.com Details: 11.5"x11.5" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships folded in half.

name: Falling Through Singing Spirits by David Orfé and 3 stories by Robert Yune (Papirmasse #17)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 17 brings together the work of travelers David Orfé & Robert Yune. David Orfé‘s work blends Victorian portraiture with Kirituhi-inspired patterns of the Maori. The result is a body of work that plays with the imagery of colonization and cultural imperialism to make a unique cultural expression. Orfé is a 26 year-old artist, originally from Lille in the north of France. His constant travels over the past four years have taken him to Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, and across Canada before landing in Montréal where he has spent the past six months. In his art, folk culture, mysticism, natural and spiritual themes meet colorful psyché patterns in a geometrical world. His materials and technical approach is informed by his travels. Side 1 features the image Falling Through Singing Spirits by David Orfé. Side 2 features 3 stories by Robert Yune. Robert Yune was born in Seoul, South Korea. His fiction has appeared or is forthcoming in The Kenyon Review, Connecticut Review, and Green Mountains Review, among others. His poetry has appeared in J Journal and The Furnace Review. Some of his past jobs include landscaper, factory worker, census enumerator, and behavioral health interviewer. He teaches at Chatham University and the University of Pittsburgh. Details: 12"x18" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping : This print ships in a tube

name: Untitled & poems by Alan Ganev (Papirmasse #16)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 16 features Untitled and 3 poems by Alan Ganev. Alan Ganev was born in Costa Rica and is currently based in Montreal. He is a collage artist and many other things: graphic designer, poet, street artist, musician, and co-founder of the multidisciplinary arts collective Cease, who throw great art parties. His meticulous collages remix images of an earlier time. He believes every work reinforces his identity and documents in a subjective way everything that is and surrounds his being. The 3 poems are from his upcoming collection of 200 short poems entitled Fatima. Details: 8.5"x8.5" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: Lost Dolls Greeting Cards (pack of 8)
description:
S. Vogelsang's eerie photographs of Beth Robinson's strange dolls are featured in this series of spooky Art Cards.

Raised in the sideshow wilderness of New York City with glimpses of Vermont, Sarah Vogelsang-Card finds beauty in the bizarre, the grotesque and often times the darkest corner and recess of the mind. "Life is just a bit more humorous if we embrace the scarier side of our humanity," she said. "Our need for light and happiness is grown in the chaos and shaped by the night. It is all an act of comedy."

Beth Robinson is a self-taught artist who started making her "Strange Dolls" in 2003. While she has dabbled in a variety of mediums, it was the discovery of polymer clay that allowed her combine her interests in sculpting, painting and sewing and gave her a concrete foundation of expression. Beth's dolls have found homes across the globe from New York to Japan. "Strange Dolls" have been featured in a number of art publications and television appearances.

This pack of eight cards includes two each of the four images.

name: Warbler by Melissa Del Pinto and poems by Shelley Thompson (Papirmasse #30)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 30 features Warbler by Melissa Del Pinto and poems by Shelley Thompson. Melissa Del Pinto is a Montreal based artist with an innate desire to wander, travel and explore the world. Her passion for painting and love for birds were discovered simultaneously in childhood and have led her to explore the fusion of these two worlds. Although we have the ability to fly we sometimes choose to be still, and in that necessary stillness lies a kind of magic. Symbolizing awareness and the forever fleeting present, birds’ inherent beauty takes centre stage in Del Pinto’s large-scale oil paintings. Her meticulously sculpted frames, made from elements of our past – toy dinosaurs and soldiers, collected shells from seaside vacations, and silk flowers from grandmothers interior gardens – are a juxtaposition to the birds they surround. See more at melissadelpinto.blogspot.ca. Shelley Thompson is an actor, writer and director living in Antigonish, Nova Scotia. Trained in London, England at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art, she worked as a leading player in the West End, at the Royal National Theatre, for BBC Radio & Television and numerous independent film and television companies in the U.K. before returning to Canada to settle in Nova Scotia with her husband and daughter, where she is perhaps best known as Barb Lahey from the hit Canadian television show Trailer Park Boys. Her extensive theatre work in Canada is complimented by her many literary achievements. She is currently working on a first volume of poetry called Constellations, a series of Christmas stories, a play-script, and a dozen Oscar award winning films scripts. Details: 8.75"x8.75" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2012 Shipping : This print ships flat

name: Dave Todaro: Switch
description: Dave Todaro‘s work is about relationships and in the case of “Switch”, his newest series of paintings, the work is about the relationship between mankind, electricity, and the natural world. At first glance, the natural world and bevy of infrastructure that delivers electricity to us could not be more distinct, but one only needs to drive into the countryside outside of Montreal to see that the network that powers the city is now as inseparable from the land as the rivers. The acrylic on wood panel paintings juxtapose industrial and natural imagery as a means of drawing a connection between man and the natural world. Dave Todaro wishes to remind the viewer, “The flip of a switch puts into motion a series of actions which inevitably affect the peoples, wildlife, and the chemical balance of the world in which we live.” About Dave Todaro Dave Todaro (b. 1978) was born and raised in Montreal, where he continues to live and work. He holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts and Teacher’s License in Arts Education, from Concordia University, Montreal (2007). He has been passionate about art since childhood. He worked as a visual arts instructor/teacher for several years, but in the end, took a leap of faith to devote all of his time and attention to his artistic practice. Todaro’s work is emotional and complex, juxtaposing humanity’s presence and intervention on the environment and its effects. The relationship between humans and their emotions, wildlife, environment, or humankind itself is represented both figuratively and abstractly in his paintings. About the Catalogue The catalogue contains full-colour images of each of the paintings with an essay and interview by Maison Kasini Director, Ric Kasini Kadour. Details: ISBN 978-0-9878094-0-7 Publisher: Maison Kasini Canada | 2011 Size: 10″x8.5″ Binding: saddle-stitched paperback 20 pages 13 images Publication ©2011 Maison Kasini Canada Images ©2011 David Todaro Text ©2011 Ric Kasini Kadour Book Design by Ric Kasini Kadour Details: 11″x8.5″ | 20 pages | 13 full colour images | ISBN: 978-0-9878094-0-7 | 2011

name: Hunks of Ice: Keith Magnuson by Marie-Maude Polychuck
description:
They walk on water with fire in their hearts and ice in their veins. They play a game that Jim Murray called Murder on Ice: High sticking, tripping, slashing, spearing, charging, hooking, fighting, unsportsmanlike conduct, interference, roughing… everything else is just figure skating. These are the Hunks of Ice.

Chicago Blackhawks Defense Keith Magnuson (born April 27, 1947 in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan; died December 15, 2003) played 589 career NHL games, all with the Chicago Blackhawks. Although he didn’t score many goals, he was a part of a solid defensive team with the Blackhawks. Perhaps his most telling statistic is his 1,442 career penalty minutes. On November 12, 2008, the Blackhawks retired Magnuson’s number 3.

Marie-Maude Polychuck presents one of hockey’s greatest players in two-color linocut on paper and mounted to old barn wood under Plexiglas.

Details: 7″x4.5″x1″ | linocut on paper with wood and Plexiglas | Edition of 14 | 2010

name: JIMMY Issue #4: Tilt-Shift LA
description: JIMMY, a queer zine from California, is a forty-to-fifty page, 5.25″x8.25″ postcard from the L.A. underground. With the Getty Museum’s Pacific Standard Time initiative turning all heads to the wealth of art in Los Angeles, JIMMY the zine decided to band wagon that momentum and celebrate some of the best queer artists in our fine city. We’ve partnered with Darin Klein’s exhibition “Tilt-Shift LA: New Queer Perspectives on the Western Edge” to feature works by its same collective of queer voices and autobiographical stories about their lives in LA. Independently published in the hills of Silver Lake and the heart of Hollywood, this quarterly explores the rich and diverse creative talents of the sprawling city of Los Angeles. Through photo editorials, interviews, art, and articles it discovers and promotes L.A.’s underground queer community. In a blog-cluttered world, JIMMY stands as a printed history, preserving and documenting a unique and city-specific cultural moment. Click here…to read more about JIMMY Details: 5.5″x8.5″ | 88 pages | black & white with glossy color cover | Published in Los Angeles, California, USA | March 2012

name: String & Tape V by Jeff Kulak & Four Poems by Guillaume Morissette (Papirmasse #13)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 13 features String & Tape V by Jeff Kulak and four poems by Guillaume Morissette. “String & Tape V” by Canadian artist Jeff Kulak is the latest in a series of works that toe the line between drawing, sculpture, and installation. Jeff uses the unconventional drawing technique of taping string to a wall and cutting it until a unique and unexpected composition is formed. He photographs the resulting linework and then translates it into a more conventional fine art form. Jeff’s string drawings ultimately make their way out of the studio and into the world in the form of screenprints, digital prints, and photographs. Papirmasse Issue 13 is a digital print measuring 12 x18 inches and is printed on archival sustainable paper. Guillaume Morissette is a Creative Writing major at Concordia, which is the closest you can get to majoring in sadness. He’s currently working on his first short story collection. His work has appeared in Lickety Split and Synapse. Guillaume lives in Montreal and writes sad emails during the winter. The following poems are by him. Click on the image twice (in this window and again in the next) to see it large. Details: 12"x18" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping: This print ships in a tube

name: Joey!
description:
Ric Kasini Kadour is a writer, artist, and galleryist. He lives in Montreal, Quebec. He primarily creates art as a photographer and sculptor. His photography explores light, colour, and abstraction. More recently, he has been photographing street life and art with an eye towards how urban life creates an organic collage of images.

Details: 9.5”x6.5” image printed on 12”x9” Byronic vellum paper | 2012 | edition of 20

name: Consignée  by Martine Frossard and three poems by Hanna Andrews (Papirmasse #23)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 23 features Consignée by Martine Frossard and three poems by Hanna Andrews About the art: A mixture of collage and painting, this piece focuses on the concept of identity quest and addiction. It takes inspiration from architecture and geometry. Martine Frossard was born in Strasbourg, France and currently lives in Montreal. Since 2007, she has worked in arts and cultural communities, most notably with the collective MassivArt. Hanna Andrews is the co-founder and co-editor of the feminist poetry press Switchback Books. She is an editor at the Academy of American Poets, where she edits the journal American Poet. Her chapbook a / long / division was published by Tilt Press in 2009, and her first book, Slope Move, is forthcoming in 2012 from Coconut Books. She lives in New York. Details: 8"x10" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping: This print ships flat

name: Seth by Christopher Schulz
description: Seth is a fantasy on Seth Rogen in the form of a collection of black-and-white drawings. Christopher Schulz is the creator of Pinups and an artist, formerly of New York City, who is soon to be based in Los Angeles. In the drawings, Schulz presents drawings of Rogen naked and in a provocative manner. The drawings are the artist’s fantasy of the actor. On Wednesday, September 28th, 2011, Seth Rogen was on Conan, an American late-night talk show hosted by Conan O’Brien to promote the movie 50/50. A centerpiece of the interview was a discussion of the book of drawings, Seth. Read about it and watch the video: HERE Details: Drawings by Christopher Schulz | 8″x6.4″ | 32 pages | Edition of 1000 | Published in New York, U.S.A. | 2011

name: Fierce Old Men Mug (1 of 6) by Sophie Eisner
description: Details: 4.375″x5″x3″ | Hand-built stoneware stained with a mix of red iron and cobalt | 2010

name: Ribbon Pig Poetry Volume One
description: Ribbon Pig Poetry Volume One CONTENTS Block Quotes by Alex Manley “cut your picture out of the mirror” Alex Manley is a journalist, Chief Copy Editor for The Link and a Creative Writing student at Concordia University. His writing is on point and eloquent, trying to make sense of the absurd. Three Poems by Ashley Opheim “tell me about your favourite fruit and how it makes you feel” The best way to visualize Ashley Opheim’s brain is as some sort of experimental Large Hadron Collider whose goal is to accelerate and multiply positive energy. Both her work and her emails often have a kind of inner wildness and playfulness to them that makes them uniquely hers. Blackface/Boldface by Roland Pemberton “like a shadow with an outline” Roland Pemberton has a heart so big that it bursts out of his aura. His writing is lyrical, poignant and direct. He served as Edmonton’s poet laureate from 2009 to 2011 and raps under the moniker Cadence Weapon. How Can So Many Do So Much And Generate So Little Meaning by Jacob Wren “You are born and you must do something whether you have something to do or not” Jacob Wren is a mastermind. His writing it part philosophical, part self-deprecating and has the ability to both embarrass and flatter the reader. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini. Details: Booklet | 7.5″ x 5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2011 | ISBN 978-0-9878094-8-3

name: Horses, Chantilly & Untitled (Look) by Monica Lacey & two poems by Sasha Fletcher (Papirmasse #22)
description: Papirmasse is an art subscription that delivers a monthly print with art on the front & writing on the back right to your mailbox. Learn more at www.papirmasse.com Issue 22 features the photographs Horses, Chantilly & Untitled (Look) by Monica Lacey and "2 poems" by Sasha Fletcher. About the art: These photographs, taken from an abandoned house, focus on themes of nostalgia, loss, tenderness, and abandonment, and the belief that objects and places have their own lives and feelings. From top: Untitled (Look) and Horse, Chantilly. Monica Lacey is a multi-disciplinary artist from Prince Edward Island whose work focuses on the beauty of the broken, overlooked, or discarded. Monica works in a variety of media including photography, printmaking, textile art, and painting. She loves alternative processes and discovering new ways to integrate different media. She draws inspiration from such things as abandoned houses, antique books, storms, and weird stop-motion animation. Monica graduated in 2011 with Honours from the New Brunswick College of Craft and Design in Fredericton, having pursued Interdisciplinary Study in Textiles and Photography. At NBCCD she was the recipient of a W. Garfield Weston Award (Canada’s largest national scholarship for college study, given for excellence in one’s field and service to one’s community) and the Governor General’s Academic Medal. Monica regularly volunteers her time in the arts community and believes deeply in the power of the arts to uplift, teach, and transform. Recently having completed a month-long residency at Spark Box Studio in Ontario where she produced a series of non-toxic photo-etchings, Monica is now working on a multi-media installation project for a solo exhibit, which will be shown at the UNB Art Centre in March 2012. She is delighted to be back in PEI after several years of living inland and having to swim in fresh water. Visit www.monicalacey.com Sasha Fletcher is the author of the novella WHEN ALL OUR DAYS ARE NUMBERED MARCHING BANDS WILL FILL THE STREETS AND WE WILL NOT HEAR THEM BECAUSE WE WILL BE UPSTAIRS IN THE CLOUDS [ml press 2010] and the chapbook I AIN’T ASKED ANY PARDON FOR ANYTHING I DONE [the greying ghost 2011]. He lives in Brooklyn, NY. Details: 12"x18" | digital print on acid-free, recycled paper | 2011 Shipping: This print ships flat

name: boring: photographs by Ric Kasini Kadour
description:
“Boring” represents a new stage of Ric Kasini Kadour’s evolution from painter to photographer to artist who works to put images on paper.

He continues to be influenced by photographers Michael Meads and Nan Goldin. Where his earlier work, such as “M Series” (2003), combined social documentary and creative portraiture to explore an individual persona, “Boring” is broader and attempts to explore interpersonal dynamics and scene.

The thirty-four page folio contains twenty-five images plus personal and artist statements and title pages. Each image is 4″x4″ on 5″x7″ paper. The folio is presented loose in a navy-coloured box. The edition is limited to one hundred and each folio is numbered, signed, and contains a certificate.

Details: Images: 4″ x 4″ on 5″ x 7″ paper in box | 34 images | 2005

name: Adjacking Sketchbook by Px(c)
description: As a companion to his May/June 2007 exhibition at Kasini House in Burlington, Vermont, Px(c) issued a limited edition sketchbook. The 8.5″x5.5″ book contains a selection of sketches, early versions and unused ideas related to the artist’s adjacking paintings. The 24-page, spiral-bound notebook is hand screenprinted by the artist and published by Art and Catastrophes. It contains 3 black & white text pages, 11 black & white image pages, and 10 two colors image pages. The edition is limited to 50. Adjacking Sketchbook is a window into the artist’s mind and process. Details: 8.5″x5.5″ | spiral bound | 2007 | Publisher: Art and Catastrophes | edition of 50 | signed & numbered on inside front cover

name: Kolaj Magazine – Issue One
description: LET’S GET THIS COLLAGE STARTED In the first issue of Kolaj Magazine, we get this party started with articles and artist folios from over a dozen countries. Kolaj Editor Benoit Depelteau interviews Boston-based Fred Free. Jp King writes about the disfigurative collage of James Gallagher and Sophie Jodoin. We learn that Liz Cohn is playing with a full deck in Portland, Oregon. Billy Mavreas tells us about Felix Morel’s overwhelming visions. Ariane Fairlie goes to Montreal’s Papier 12 and reports back on the collage she found. Audrey Smith shows us her studio. And we feature ortfolios from collage artists in Hartford, Connecticut; Chicago, Illinois; New York City; Madrid, Spain; & Johannesburg, South Africa. Details: 10″x8″ | perfect bound | 68 full color pages ISSN 1927-6893 | Published by Maison Kasini

name: Kolaj Magazine – Special Pre-Issue: “Why Collage? Why Now?”
description: Contents Benoit Depelteau: Why Collage? | Jp King: The Parenting Techniques of the Collage Artist | Aprile Elcich: Life On Paper | Carl David Ruttan: Remake The World | Meaghan Thurston: Collage Artists, Mediaspheres, & Scopo-maniacs | Edvard Derkert: Collage Not Glue | Ric Kasini Kadour: Collage Is the Moment | Artist Portfolios | The Future of Kolaj Magazine | The Cut-Out Page Details: 10″x8″ | saddle-stitch | 54 pages | illustrated | Published by Maison Kasini | 2011

name: Charles Orme: Icarus & Putto
description: Iamque novum delectat iter, positoque timore Icarus audaci fortius arte volat. Now Icarus delights in the strange journey, and, fear forgotten, he flies more swiftly, with daring art. –from Ovid’s The Art of Love “Charles Orme: Icarus & Putto” presents a group of work in which the artist enacts a series of fantasies, documented in photographs. In the Icarus series, Orme re-enacts the Greek myth in his studio. The walls are painted like sky and are decorated with polyester clouds. Two box fans hang to the side. The artist is suspended, naked, in the middle of the composition in various states of ascension and plummeting. The photographs are tableaux vivants that explore the artists folly in rich colors and classical compositions. In the Putto series, Orme presents himself as a cherub dangling from a sculptural cloud. “I was inspired to create a photographic series/performance that created entertaining conflict in the relationships between earthly and celestial bodies, gravity and loft, artifice and nature, and fantasy and reality.” Born in 1980, Orme studied art at the University of Vermont and the Marschutz School, Aix-en-Provence (France). He lives and works in Vermont and New York City. His works have been exhibited in the United States (Vermont and New Jersey), France and the Netherlands. This catalogue presents the work exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal. The exhibition presented the full Icarus series, selections from the Putto series, including “Putto Interior”, “Putto Dawn” and “Putto Night”, and the cloud Orme constructed to use in photographing the Putto series. The catalogue contains an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour, artist statements, reproductions of some of the artist’s preliminary sketches and 16 images. Details: 6″x8.5″ | 32 pages | 16 images | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-1-8 | 2010

name: Yvon Goulet: Animal by Maison Kasini
description: “Yvon Goulet is not a pop artist in the truest sense of the term. Goulet uses the methodology of pop art and its unique ability to present the everyday, the mundane, without moral or personal comment. He employs some of the same techniques as pop art, that is, the use of appropriated or found imagery and photomechanical reproduction. His subject, however, is neither celebrity nor mass media; rather, his focus is on subjects often passed over by mainstream or mass culture.” Quebec-artist Yvon Goulet has built a reputation for himself as an “urban folklorist”. He finds his inspiration in Montreal’s Gay Village and illustrates the cultural events and festivities of the gay community. He presents daily reality and features the male body. In his works, he represents the symbols, the uniforms and fantasies which are specific to the gay culture. In so doing, he takes situations and imagery reserved for the few and makes them accessible to all. He paints on polyester panels used during election campaigns. He uses the text of the political posters on which he paints as integral parts of his work. In a departure from his typical subject, “Yvon Goulet: Animal” presents a menagerie of work where the subject is non-human: bears, pigs, cows, goats, wolves, bats, and mosquitos. He says, “I want to pay tribute to some animals that we eat or spend our life with everyday without looking at them anymore. A steer isn’t just some red meat wrapped in plastic on a plate of styrofoam…it is also a being who has feelings just like ours.” Yvon Goulet: Animal contains over 40 images of the artist’s animal-themed art work and an essay Ric Kasini Kadour. Born 1956 in Quebec City, Yvon Goulet lives in Montreal. Since 1986, he has shown in many countries, including Canada, France, South Korea, Bulgaria, Austria, Japan, Belgium, Bosnia-Herzegovina, the United States, Spain, as well as the United Arab Emirates. He finished a baccalaureate at Université du Québec à Hull in 1988. In 1989 he collaborated with the University of Ottawa’s Philip Fry on a land art project in Oxford-on-Rideau, Ontario. He participated in several national and international exhibitions. In 2003, he exhibited an artist’s book Touche ça at Galerie 303 in the Belgo Building, Montreal; he was part of the traveling exhibition “The Gay Body” at Vieux Palais, Saint-Jérome, Quebec, (2002); he presented an artist’s book, Danger, at IV Rencontres Internationales, Marseille, France (2001); L’art et le papier IV, Jean-Claude Bergeron Gallery, Ottawa (2000); Sen-Art, biennial, Vert-Saint-Denis, France (1998); Mostra Int. Minigravats, Barcelona, Spain(1997); Kanagawa 18th Print International, Japan (1995); Musée Adzak, Paris (1993); and Arts 1992 ULB, Brussels, Belgium (1992). He has also shown at the QUAB Gallery in Calgary and at Kasini House Gallery in Burlington, Vermont (2007). This catalog was published in conjunction with the exhibition “Yvon Goulet: Animal” held at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal, Quebec. The catalogue contains an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour that explore’s Goulet’s technical and conceptual approach to art making and places Goulet’s animal-themed artwork in context to his work documenting gay life. Details: 6″x8.5″ | 36 pages | 45 images | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-5-6 | 2010

name: Helen Shulman: A Catalog of Recent Paintings
description: Vermont artist Helen Shulman once said, “I paint to keep Psyche happy.” As a psychotherapist, Shulman works to ease the soul and psyche of others, but with her paintings she soothes her own internal state. One would be remiss to categorize Shulman’s paintings with other artists who subject the public to self-indulgent, narcissistic creative endeavors. Such painters claim “art is therapy”, by which we mean art is their therapy and we sould pay attention to them because, put simply, they want attention. Shulman offers the viewer a substance far greater. As she says, “While the act of painting is an entirely private affair, the result isn’t.” Helen Shulman: A Catalog of Recent Paintings features Ric Kasini Kadour’s essay “Helen Shulman’s Lyrical Abstrations” in which he documents the artist’s expert use of visual language to make deeply personal painting universally accessible. The essay also explores the the artist’s work as a contemporary expression of Lyrical Abstraction. West Branch Gallery and Sculpture Park published the catalog in conjunction with an exhibition of Shulman’s work at West Branch Gallery, Stowe, Vermont, March 7-April 26, 2009. Details: 8.5″x9″ | 27 pages | 21 full colour illustrations | Published by West Branch Gallery | 2009

name: The Fireman by Trevor Barton with illustration by Claire Milbrath
description: The Fireman by Trevor Barton with illustration by Claire Milbrath “I want you to take me to a place of unimaginable terror.” Trevor Barton’s “The Fireman” evokes an intense nostalgia through its imagery, creating conflict through the questionable danger that foresees the two characters. What is danger? What is worth saying? What is worth keeping secret? Claire Milbrath’s drawings are calming to look at. It’s like they are whispering, ‘feel better, feel better.’ Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini. Details: Tri-fold Pamphlet | 6″ x 8″ | 2011 | ISBN 978-0-9878094-6-9

name: Frog Hollow: The First 40 Years of the Nation’s First State Craft Center
description: 2010 edited by Robert Hunter with text by Rachel Esch and others, foreword by Senator Patrick Leahy Book Since 1971, Frog Hollow Vermont State Craft Center has supported and celebrated individual design and craftsmanship through the exhibition and sale of fine traditional and contemporary Vermont craft. Over the course of 40 years, five hundred juried artisans, who live and work in communities throughout Vermont, have been making craft by hand with loving care and attention to detail. Frog Hollow is the first state craft center in the United States and the organization has served as a model for countless others across the country. Kasini House Books is pleased to announce the publication of Frog Hollow: The First 40 Years of the Nation’s First State Craft Center. “Frog Hollow” contains countless images, a foreword by Senator Patrick Leahy, a history by Rachel Esch, and first-person recollections by seventeen craftspeople and almost every organization director since Frog Hollow’s founding. Frog Hollow: The First 40 Years of the Nation’s First State Craft Center surveys the history of this pioneering organization and examines how a group of people came together to build and nurture Frog Hollow over the last 40 years. It documents the impact of the creative economy on Vermont and its small, rural communities. The book provides a snapshot of the influence of the Back to the Land Movement on Vermont and how Frog Hollow is part of its legacy. Frog Hollow: The First 40 Years of the Nation’s First State Craft Center tells the story of how a disparate group of artisans, with the support of Coca-Cola heir Allen Johnson, came together in the spirit of community. The influence of craft and the role craftmakers play in Vermont is highlighted through biography, recollection and images, including Danforth Pewter, Peter Miller, Elfriede Abbe, Sabra Field, and Woody Jackson. Through first person accounts and an early history written by Rachel Esch, the book follows the rise of Frog Hollow through the 70s, 80s and 90s; its struggles in the first decade of this century; and its continuing path today. DETAILS Title: Frog Hollow: The First 40 Years of the Nation’s First State Craft Center Edited by Robert Hunter with text by Rachel Esch and others, foreword by Senator Patrick Leahy ISBN 978-0-9771397-8-1 Trim Size: 6″w x 9″h Binding: Paperback, perfect bound Page Count: 150+ pages Cover: Full Color Illustrations: 75+ Publisher: Kasini House Books Release Date: September 1st, 2010

name: Roleplay by Lizy Mostowski
description: “I itched, following the bugs crawling up my neck, like pins and needles, through my hair, to the crown of my head. I wondered if there were any bed bugs at the Motel 6.” Lizy Mostowski co-curates the (excellent) reading series Synapse and is the editor-in-chief of Soliloquies Anthology. Her story, “Roleplay”, is funny but doesn’t feel far-fetched. Her narrative voice allows her to both feel and be felt vulnerable. Each booklet cover is unique and contains a splash painting made with borscht, which may make more sense after you read the story. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini. Details: Booklet | 6.25″ x 6″ | unique cover contains a splash painting made with borscht | Saddle-stitch | 2011 | ISBN 978-0-9878094-4-5

name: JIMMY Issue Number 2: “The Greenwood”
description:
We’ve really raised the bar this time. With double the page count, we’ve included twice as many beautiful two page photo spreads, interviews with some of L.A.’s most interesting homosexuals, and some great art and writing pieces from this city’s vibrant queer art scene.

Issue No.2 Editor’s note:

“The pigeons are humping, the Jacaranda trees are covering the city in purple and the first Summertramp of the season kicked it all off like a wet and  drunken, urban Bacchanal. It’s that time of year in Los Angeles when you just want be outside, in one of the many natural spaces Angelinos are lucky to have all around us. Whether barbecuing at Bellevue, hiking up Griffith, or cruising in Elysian, the parks are calling your name. Its time for day trips to El Matador, Angeles Crest or Topanga Canyon, and weekend getaways to the deserts of Joshua Tree, the redwoods of Sequoia, or the beach towns of the great California coast.

Wherever you choose to go to commune with nature, the important thing is that you get out there and you do it. Maybe you’re Phyllis Nefler from  Troop Beverly Hills and need a cappuccino by your campfire. Fine, grab your battery-operated bean grinder and go. The massive migration of gay people into metropolitan cities in search of acceptance and community has centered homo culture around urban things. I love bar nights and beer busts as much as the next fag, but the connections made among men while out in nature are unique.

For centuries queer authors have written about running off into the Greenwood, away from the stares and stigmas of society, to find the freedom to be our gay selves. Though we no longer have to seclude our sexuality, Brokeback Mountain style in remote mountain hide-aways, there’s still something special about taking it back to more primitive times. Connecting nature to the natural bonds of love and friendship we form with each other creates a dynamic that’s different than what we experience in our big city lives. This is not a radical call to action. You don’t have to abandon your cars and condos and move to Alaska (or Tennessee). I love the city too much for that. I simply urge you to appreciate the abundance of nature we have around us, and spend a bit more time among the birds and the bees.”

Details: 8.5″x5.5″ | 84 pages | black & white with full color cover | Published in Los Angeles, California, USA  | Summer 2011

name: Pinups No. 6 featuring Scott
description: Pinups is a fresh take on the notion of the Pin Up Girl, as embodied by Betty Grable in the 1940s. But these Pin Ups are men. And not the airbrushed, pumped up men of contemporary advertising, but men with facial and body hair, men with bulk, and men together. Pinups is a triannual publication that features one male nude pictorial per issue. There are no words—just an exaggeration of the classic centerfold. Each magazine exists in book form, but can be taken apart and tiled to reveal a 32″x70″ image. Details: Produced by Christopher Schulz | 10″x8″ | 26 black-and-white images over 56 pages | Edition of 1000 | Published in New York, U.S.A. | June 2008

name: Senryu and Nudes by Marc Awodey
description: Award-winning poet and renowned Vermont artist, Marc Awodey offers a collection of visual and written poetry. Senryu & Nudes juxtaposes drawings of nude figures with senryu, a Japanese style of poetry. Like haiku, senryu is a short form of poetry that consists of three lines with seventeen or fewer phonetic units. Unlike haiku, where the subject is nature, senryu trades in the foibles of man, treating its subject with dark humor and cynicism. “The point of combining senryu and nudes is to suggest that poems must evolve from a state of psychological nudity,” writes Awodey. The drawings in the book are poetic moments in and of themselves, rendered in a loose, gestural style. Some of the drawings have been torn apart and what is presented are the ripped fragments of paper that form a collage on the page. The volume includes an opening essay by Janaka Stucky Details: 5.25″ x 8.25″ | 2008 | perfect bound paperback | 90 pages | 35 images | Publisher: Kasini House Books | ISBN: 0-9771397-7-8 | 2008

name: Ten Days in the Mountains by Cody Hicks
description: “Kazbegi is nestled in a valley in the Greater Caucuses, a range eerily similar to the Canadian Rockies if they were littered with ancient crumbling castles, churches and roads.” In grade 7, Cody Hicks had a lion’s mane for hair. He now has a degree in journalism and writes personal essays that are straightforward, entertaining and totally hilarious. This booklet contains Hicks’ non-fiction essay as well as photographs from his trip to Kazbegi. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini.

name: Ball Presents Itself by Rosa Aiello
description: “I dream that I hold a delicate ball made of glass that glows in internal concentric layers like an animal eye.” Rosa Aiello has a presence that makes you wish she’d share everything she is thinking. Her story, “Ball Presents Itself,” is maze-like, filled with weird images and fleeting characters. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini Details: Booklet | 6″ x 4.5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2011 | ISBN 978-0-9878094-7-6

name: History of the Northern Vermont Artist Association by Robert Waldo Brunelle, Jr.
description: “To encourage the study, improve the practice, elevate the standards and advance the cause of creative art.” That was the mission of the Northern Vermont Artist Association when it was founded in 1931. For most of the twentieth century, this organization has fostered and supported artists in northern Vermont and held an annual exhibition of their art work. Maxfield Parrish, Francis Colburn, Stan Marc Wright, Alden Bryan Sr. and his wife Mary Bryan are just a few of their notable members. Artist and historian Robert Waldo Brunelle, Jr. offers this history of the organization. Brunelle has been president of the NVAA since 1995 and studied under former NVAA president, and renowned art professor, Roy Kennedy. This is the definitive history of this important art organization. The phrase “Vermont Artist” fits no one better than Robert Waldo Brunelle, Jr. He is a seventh-generation Vermonter, with roots dating back to the 1750’s. He counts among his artistic ancestors a great-grandfather, great-grandmother and great-great grandfather, all of whom were painters. Brunelle was born in Rutland, Vermont in 1958. As he puts it, ”I learned to draw before I learned to write!” Although he drew incessantly as a child, he received no formal art training until attending St. Michael’s College in 1976. There he fell under the influence of former NVAA president, and renowned art professor, Roy Kennedy, well-known painter Lance Richbourg, and the namesake of the Sloane Art Center, Sy Sloane. Brunelle graduated in 1980 with a double degree in History and Fine Arts, and went on to earn a Master’s in Art Education at Castleton State College. Since 1981 he has been the art teacher at the Browns River Middle School, in Underhill–a post once held by Roy Kennedy in the 1950’s! Brunelle has been exhibiting his paintings in Vermont since 1975, and has served as the president of the NVAA since 1995. He is also a political cartoonist, whose strip “Mr. Brunelle Explains It All” may be seen in the humor magazine Funny Times. DETAILS: 7.5″ x 5.5″ | saddle stitched | 24 pages | 6 images | Publisher: Kasini House Books | 2009

name: One For My Baby, and One More for the Road by Alan Alejo
description: Details: 2.75″x3.5″ | oil on wood | 2010

name: “Amuse Bouche”: limited-edition folio by Alan Ganev
description: An amuse bouche is a small, bite-sized hors d’oeuvre offered by the chef as an introduction to his cooking. In this spirit, Maison Kasini is pleased to offer a folio of six prints by Costa Rican-born, Montreal artist Alan Ganev. “Amuse Bouche” is a folio of six, 12”x12” prints by Alan Ganev: Passing By, F&B, Sterling, BUBLÉ, Pajarito, and Killing Appetite. The folios are presented in a black sleeve and signed by the artist. The folio will be officially released at Papier 11, Montreal’s contemporary art fair of works on paper, April 14th to April 17th, 2011. The original six works will debut at Rouge 58 in Brooklyn in May 2011. About Alan Ganev Originally from Costa Rica, collage artist Alan Ganev has been calling Montreal home for several years. Ganev is meticulous in his process. He cuts the images delicately and is exact about the position and alignment of the elements in the composition. The compositions are rich, yet simple, using no more than three images, some geometrical shapes and bright colours. Ganev says about his work: “I spend hours going through forgotten publications looking for images to steal my attention. Once I choose a couple of images I want to work with, these images start sending me messages, and as a result, I start making connections with them. Sometimes these connections are profound and emotional and some other times they are casual and humorous.” Alan Ganev is currently completing his Bachelor of Fine Arts in Design at Concordia University and is also a co-founder of CEASE, a non-profit artist collective in Montreal that diffuses art through events, blog, magazine and art initiative. Details: 6 prints measuring 12” x 12” on paper | The folio is presented loose in a black sleeve with a white label | 2011 | Edition of 50

name: The Hat Is the Worst Part by Rowan Cornell-Brown
description: “Some of the poems were very good and some were not. Some I thought might have been good if I’d understood them better.” Rowan Cornell-Brown is a graduate from Concordia University’s Creative Writing program. He also plays in a band called Goose Hut. His story, “The Hat is the Worst Part”, is not really about a hat. His narrative style feels compassionate and comical but also quietly intense. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini Details: Booklet | 8.5″ x 3.5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2011 | ISBN 978-0-9878094-3-8

name: Charles Louis Heyde: 19th Century Vermont Landscape Painter
description:
This publication catalogues the works of Charles Louis Heyde. Published in conjunction with the Spring 2001 exhibition at the University of Vermont’s Robert Hull Fleming Museum, the volume includes 28 full-color images of Heyde’s paintings. Also featured are essays by University of Vermont art professor William C. Lipke and Heyde biographer Barbara Hamblett.

Details: 100 pages | paperback | 28 color illustrations | Published by the Robert Hull Fleming Museum | ISBN 978-0-9346580-9-6 | 2001

name: Luis London: Repercussions
description: Luis London explores the emotional impact of childhood experience on adult lives in a series of paintings titled, “Repercussions”. The paintings are rendered in a style that combines contemporary graphic design and American Pop Art. As portraits, they are Warhol-esque: square with bold, deep colours and shapes reminiscent of screenprinting. London introduces texture and complexity with patterns that cast light and shadow onto a simple rendering. The result is big, bold paintings that convey their intense emotional experiences: joy, rage, surprise, helplessness. For adult viewers, these paintings are intended to be a connection between a current, developed emotional state and the raw, untempered emotions of our past. About Luis London Luis London comes from a traditional illustration and graphic design background. He began to experiment painting at an early age, following the teachings of his father, an art teacher by trade. He studied at the Bribiesca Design Institute in Guadalajara, Mexico. He lives and works in Montreal. This catalogue presents the work exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal. The catalogue includes a 20-minute sound piece on CD-R created by the artist and also entitled Repercussions. Each situation that we live through during our childhood can have an impact as we grow up, these sounds are meant to express the aforementioned experiences and support each art piece and the series as a whole. The catalogue contains an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour, the above-mentioned sound art disc and 10 images. Details: 11″x8.5″ | 28 pages | 10 full colour illustrations and accompanying 20-minute sound art disc | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-3-2 | 2010

name: Beautiful Books by Mark Ambrose Harris
description: “Consider some of the literary works that have aroused you.” Mark Ambrose Harris is a Montreal-based writer. His Twitter bio describes him as a “queer ear, with a touch of fauna.” His personal essay, “Beautiful Books,” is brave, accessible, imaginative and witty. Published by Ribbon Pig, a literary imprint of Maison Kasini Details: Booklet | 7′” x 5″ | Saddle-stitch | 2011 | ISBN 978-0-9878094-5-2

name: Lois Eby: From Landscape to Jazz
description:
Lois Eby’s artwork is the result of a forty-year exploration of painting. The connection between painting and music, specifically the improvisation of American Jazz, is at the heart of Eby’s work. Her colours are often primary. Her compositions are rich with rhythms. Brushwork is informed by Zen ink paintings and Asian calligraphy. The result is a beautiful harmonic where paint plays against white space, gesture dances across the canvas, and music is made visual.

The catalog features the essay “Lois Eby: From Landscape to Jazz” by Ric Kasini Kadour, who explores the development of Eby’s work from 1980 to the present.

Maison Kasini published the catalog in conjunction with the exhibition “Lois Eby: Visual Jazz” at Galerie Maison Kasini, Montreal, June 24-July 31, 2010.

Details: 10.75″x8″ | 28 pages | 24 full colour illustrations | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-4-9 | 2010

name: Hunks of Ice: Frank Mahovlich by Marie-Maude Polychuck
description:
They walk on water with fire in their hearts and ice in their veins. They play a game that Jim Murray called Murder on Ice: High sticking, tripping, slashing, spearing, charging, hooking, fighting, unsportsmanlike conduct, interference, roughing… everything else is just figure skating. These are the Hunks of Ice.

Detroit Red Wings Left Wing Frank “The Big M” Mahovlich (born January 10, 1938 in Timmins, Ontario) played on six Stanley Cup-winning teams and is an inductee of the Hockey Hall of Fame. In 1998, Mahovlich was appointed to the Senate of Canada by Prime Minister Jean Chrétien, and in the same year, he was ranked number 27 on The Hockey News‘ list of the 100 Greatest Hockey Players, the highest-ranking player who had spent at least a majority of his career with the Maple Leafs.

Marie-Maude Polychuck presents one of hockey’s greatest players in two-color linocut on paper and mounted to old barn wood under Plexiglas.

Details: 7″x4.5″x1″ | linocut on paper with wood and Plexiglas | Edition of 34 | 2010

name: La commedia é Finita by Misanthrope Specialty Company
description: Details: 7″x5″ | xerography | unframed | 2010

name: Daryl Vocat: Awkward Moments
description: Selections from Rules of the Playground (2002) Practical Associations (2004) A Boy’s Will (2005) The Translator’s Conundrum (2006) Pact for Adventure (2007) with an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour Maison Kasini is pleased to announce the publication of Daryl Vocat: Awkward Moments. Daryl Vocat’s art is forthcoming, downright friendly, Canadian friendly. His prints invite you in like a cordial neighbour who offers you a glass of lemonade and a slice of pie. Bold, black lines and bright off-primary colours put a viewer at ease. A familiar visual language that borrows heavily from vintage imagery and comic illustration make for a comfortable read. But as you take in the prints, one realizes that the world of Daryl Vocat is not all lollipops and roses. It is a world teeming with angst and alienation, sexual intimacy and power play. And that realization is the awkward moment of his artwork. About Daryl Vocat Daryl Vocat, born in Regina, Saskatchewan, is a visual artist living and working in Toronto. He completed his Bachelor of Fine Arts degree at the University of Regina in Saskatchewan, and his Master of Fine Arts degree at York University in Toronto. His main focus is printmaking, specifically screen printing. He works out of Toronto’s Open Studio. He has had solo exhibitions at Toronto’s Thrush Holmes Empire, Open Studio, and York Quay Gallery. He has also had solo exhibitions at SNAP gallery and Latitude 53 in Edmonton, Eastern Edge Gallery in St John’s, James K. Bartleman Art Gallery in Elliot Lake, The Wilfred Laurier Gallery in Waterloo, and Malaspina Printmakers Gallery in Vancouver. He has participated in several group exhibitions both in Canada and beyond, including an internationally touring exhibition titled “Further, Artists From Printmaking at the Edge”. Most recently he had work in the New Prints exhibition at the International Print Center New York. His work has been acquired by the National Gallery of Canada Library and Archives, The Robert Blackburn Printmaking Workshop in NYC, The Morris and Helen Belkin Art Gallery permanent collection in British Columbia, The Saskatchewan Arts Board permanent collection, and the City of Toronto Fine Art collection. His artwork has been published in YYZine from YYZ Gallery in Toronto, Briarpatch magazine from Regina, and Printmaking at the Edge by Richard Noyce, published in Great Britain. About the Catalogue The catalogue presents the work exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal. The catalogue contains an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour that explores Vocat’s work from 2002 to 2007 and 34 full-colour images. Details: ISBN 978-0-9865298-6-3 Publisher: Maison Kasini Canada | 2011 Size: 11″x8.5″ Binding: saddle stitched 28 pages 34 full color images Publication ©2011 Maison Kasini Canada Images ©2011 Daryl Vocat Book Design by Ric Kasini Kadour Details: 11″x8.5″ | 28 pages | 34 full colour | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-6-3 | 2011

name: Captain’s Log: An Installation in a Box by Katie Loesel
description: This installation in a box contains twenty-seven cards one can arrange at their own discretion to recreate Katie Loesel’s Captain’s Log. The original Captain’s Log is a 7-foot installation of monoprints (oil-based intaglio inks on Johannot paper) that was completed in 2007. The abstracted landscapes map a journey through an imaginary utopia of land, sky, and water. In addition to reproductions of the prints on cards, the box contains instructions for recreating the installation on their own wall, bulletin board, rear car window, bathroom stall door, or other appropriate space. Katie Loesel grew up on Lake Erie in Erie, Pennsylvania. She is a 2007 graduate of the Cleveland Institute of Art in Cleveland, Ohio, where she received a BFA in Printmaking. Upon graduation, she received the Agnes Gund Traveling Scholarship Award. She now lives in Boston. She has exhibited her work at the Bundy Center for the Arts in Waitsfield and at Kasini House in Burlington. Katie is a printmaker, bookmaker, drawer, crafter, cyclist, and sailor, amongst other things. Loesel was the winner of the 2008 Vermont Contemporary Art Annual Cover Award, and the publication of this “installation in a box” is part of that award. The Vermont Contemporary Art Annual showcases the work of Vermont artists. Each year, the publishers select one artist to be featured on the cover. That artist is given a publishing contract. This nifty multiple is a great way to bring installation art into your home or office. Details: 7″x5.5″x1″ box with 27 cards of various dimensions and one 12″x12″ print with text | edition of 100 | signed and numbered by the artist | 2008

name: Monument Catastrophe: Fire by Px(c)
description: Details: 7″ x 5″ | Collage and acrylic paint on mounting board | Unique 1 of 1 | 2012

name: Open House
description:
Curated by Amy Rahn, “Open House” is an art exhibition that explores “home” as a concept detached from the familiar architecture of the house. Artists Angelo Arnold, Kate Brandt, and Mary Zompetti each approach the meaning of “home” from richly varied perspectives. Arnold’s “familiarture” upholstered sculptures, Brandt’s insightful, darkly humorous video works, and Zompetti’s ephemeral, meditative photographic works re-interpret the space and essence of “house” and “home”, grounding the viewer in a contemplative space. Here, viewers are invited to see “home” as a concept open to interpretation, and a space open to exploration.

Artists include:
Angelo Arnold
Kate Brandt
Mary Zompetti

This catalog accompanied an exhibition of the same title that took place June 22nd to August 4th, 2012 during the Winooski Pop-up Gallery District.

DETAILS: 28 pages | full-color | saddle-stitched | ISBN 978-0-9837060-2-1 | published by Kasini House Books

name: How To Price Your Artwork by Ric Kasini Kadour
description: Ric Kasini Kadour offers this humorous look at how artists price their work. How to Price Your Artwork was originally presented during a panel discussion on April 28, 2005 titled “Pricing Artwork to Sell” hosted by South End Arts and Business Association in Burlington, Vermont. The twenty-page, saddle-stitched, 4.25” x 7” chapbook contains the 375 word essay. A full-color cover presents a collage of Kadour’s paintings on the front and an untitled work on the back. Each book is signed and numbered. This edition is limited to 100 books. Details: 7″x4.25″ | saddle-stitched bound | 20 pages, illustrated cover | September 2005 | Edition of 100

name: Mutual Gaze/Call & Response
description:
Curator and artist Riki Moss brings together six Vermont artists all of whose work explores humankind’s relationship to the environment, and specifically how the natural world communicates with humanity when it is in peril.

“If we look gently and long at the natural world, it begins to return our gaze,” said curator Riki Moss. “Listen and you will hear the world listening to you.”

Artists include:
Cami Davis
Janet Fredericks
Emiko Sawaragi Gilbert
Linda E. Jones
Riki Moss
Janet Van Fleet

This catalog accompanied an exhibition of the same title that took place June 22nd to August 4th, 2012 during the Winooski Pop-up Gallery District.

DETAILS: 28 pages | full-color | saddle-stitched | ISBN 978-0-9837060-1-4 | published by Kasini House Books

name: Auditorium by Yann Novak & Jamie Drouin
description: Auditorium is a live sound collaboration between Seattle artist Yann Novak and Victoria artist Jamie Drouin. The two artists first met on a panel discussion hosted by Seattle’s 2006 Decibel Festival at the Henry Art Gallery, and both immediately recognized a connection between their two bodies of sound work; using altered field recordings and sharing a mutual interest in exploring the ability of sound to alter the atmosphere of spaces we inhabit–physically and emotionally. Two months later, the two artists met once again at the Henry Art Gallery to perform Auditorium, which uses the performance space itself as a sonic point of departure. Recordings made by Novak of the empty space were amplified and layered to create a singular, modulating drone which enhanced the particular “fingerprint” of the space. Drouin’s approach was to define the space with a more scalpel-like hand, inserting sonic pings and rhythms which called attention to the depth and scale of the auditorium, and to interject more textual sounds which would occasionally push the listeners attention outside of the building, reminding them of the thin membrane between the inside/outside worlds. Details: sound recording | 5″ CD-R | 48:17 | Publisher: Dragon’s Eye Recordings | Edition of 400 | 2007

name: Printoptik by Carl David Ruttan
description: Maison Kasini announces the publication of Printoptik by Carl David Ruttan. How do we read the collage work of Carl David Ruttan? Printoptik acts as a lens presenting several points of view on this question. Essays by Mark Grenon, Meaghan Thurston, and Henri Michaud explore the different ways in which the artist uses collage in his work. Ruttan produces a large body of small art collages while travelling. His source material is bits of found paper collected while walking the streets of lands both foreign and familiar. At home, he blows-up the collage to make a one-of-a-kind fine art print that explores the micro-world of paper. Ruttan has also taken thousands of photographs of “found collage”: images of layered and torn posters, paints and textures. The processes of street photography, decollage and collage merge to take the reader on a visual journey. Printoptik is a visual feast. The book is lavishly illustrated with Ruttan’s colourful images. Three critical essays describe Ruttan’s work as reflections on collecting, diary keeping, ripping, tearing, reclaiming, printing, and especially seeing. About Carl David Ruttan A consummate traveler, Carl David Ruttan makes collages with graphic ephemera he finds along the way: Chinese cigarette cartons, Indian candy wrappers, torn bits of music posters from the street. Working in a rented room in Berlin, a youth hostel in Switzerland, on the beach in India, or his apartment in Montreal, Ruttan spreads out the fragments and brings the bits and pieces together in composition. When done, he slides the small 3.75” x 2.75” collages into a plastic sleeve. At Atelier Circulaire in Montreal, Ruttan scans them at extremely high resolution, and produces one unique print to accompany the original collage as the final, archivally stable work of art. The final photographic quality digital print creates a convincing tactile optic which the eye perceives as an original collage. Carl David Ruttan was born in 1976 in Oshawa, Ontario. He studied fine art at the University of Ottawa, completing his Bachelors of Fine Art in 2000. He has traveled extensively in Asia, North America, Europe and on numerous islands of the Caribean and South Pacific. Carl Settled in Montreal in 2001 after his first trip to Asia. Ruttan is an active member of both the printmaking workshop Atelier Circulaire and Montreal artist-run centre Articule. Like many contemporary artists, Ruttan’s art making practice includes many mediums. He makes small dry-point intaglio and relief prints that offer a unique aesthetic and a simple, accessible style. He takes macro photographs of found objects, urban scenes, and textures of various sorts—paint, plywood, brick—and blows them up. He has maked some sculpture and he paints with acrylic on canvas and wood. Yet, it is in his collage work that the dominant themes of his art practice come together. Multi-layered, texture-rich colour compositions are composed from the colours and images that printed media lay before the artist as he navigates the sea of symbols around him. They are both the vehicle for self-expression, and limiting agent, determining the palette and tiny details of paper quality that will define the final work. About the Book The book presents the collage work of Carl David Ruttan. It was launched in conjunction with Ruttan’s solo show, “Trusted Everywhere by Everyone”, exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal, October 19-November 19, 2011. The book contains full-colour images with essays by Meaghan Thurston, Mark Grenon, and Henri Michaud. About Meaghan Thurston: Meaghan Thurston has published reviews of visual art and culture in The Rover: Montreal Arts Uncovered and an essay on the American photographer Francesca Woodman in Forum: The University of Edinburgh’s Journal of Arts and Culture. Her text and photographs on the site-specific art installations of British artist Katy Bentall were published in November 2011 in Onsite Review, Calgary. About Mark Grenon: A native of Ottawa, Mark Grenon has taught English in the Czech Republic, Taiwan, and Chile. He currently lives in Montreal, where his interests include poetry and poetics, digital photography, and painting. About Henri Michaud: Coming from a background in black and white film photography, Henri quickly jumped into the digital realm while refusing to surrender the processing of prints to commercial laboratories. He strongly believes that the photographic process does not end when the shutter closes. He has worked for years in the newspaper industry providing photo manipulation services and running pre-press departments. Details: ISBN 978-0-9878094-1-4 Publisher: Maison Kasini Canada | 2011 Size: 9″x7″ Binding: perfect-bound paperback 66 pages full colour images Publication ©2011 Maison Kasini Canada Images ©2011 Carl David Ruttan Text ©2011 Mark Grenon, Henri Michaud, Meaghan Thurston, Carl David Ruttan Book Design by Patsy Hayes

name: This Little Piggy 1 by Alan Alejo
description: Details: 2.75″x3.125″ | oil on wood | 2010

name: Pinups #15 featuring Micka
description: Pinups is a fresh take on the notion of the Pin Up Girl, as embodied by Betty Grable in the 1940s. But these Pin Ups are men. And not the airbrushed, pumped up men of contemporary advertising, but men with facial and body hair, men with bulk, and men together. Pinups is a triannual publication that features one male nude pictorial per issue. There are no words—just an exaggeration of the classic centerfold. Each magazine exists in book form, but can be taken apart and tiled to reveal a 32″x70″ image. Details: Produced by Christopher Schulz | 10″x8″ | 26 black-and-white images over 56 pages | Edition of 1000 | Published in New York, U.S.A. | September 2011

name: Carol MacDonald: Knit Monoprints & Drawings
description:
Carol MacDonald invites the viewer to see her works “as prints of and about knitting and as conceptual works about teaching, the art of printing, community.” The catalog is yet another of the many ways that MacDonald shares her artistic process with the larger community. MacDonald says about the work in this book, “I love that this makes the stitch large enough that you actually have to walk past it. It makes me laugh. There’s something sort of joyful about it.”

The catalog features the essay “Carol MacDonald: The Thread and the Fabric” by curator Amy Rahn, who highlights MacDonald’s career and, especially, her artistic investigation of the medium of knitting.

Kasini House published the catalog in conjunction with an exhibition of MacDonald’s prints, “Cast On, Bind Off”, at the Firehouse Gallery, Burlington, Vermont, September 26-November 1, 2008.

Details: 8.5″x9″ | 36 pages | 42 full colour illustrations | 2008

name: Raise the Roof, Renée by Karen M. Geiger
description: Details: 13″ x 9.5″ | acrylic, conté, oil stick, found images on paper | framed | 2008

name: Hello From Vermont: Contemporary Art from the Green Mountain State
description: In this 2011 catalog of Vermont art, Maison Kasini Gallery Director Ric Kasini Kadour presents the work of thirty-five contemporary artists. The work includes painting, sculpture, ceramics, fiber, and installation from some of states’s leading artists: Anna Ayres | Brian Zeigler | Candy Barr | Carol MacDonald | Ciaran Brennan | Elizabeth Nelson | Eric Tobin | Irene Lederer LaCroix | Jayne Shoup | Kat Clear | Linda Durkee | Lois Eby | Longina Smolinski | Marni McKitrick | Robert Waldo Brunelle, Jr. | Winnie Looby | Alex Costantino | Alisa Dworsky | Anne Cummings | Brian O’Neill | Lynn Rupe | Eve Jacobs-Carnahan | James Vogler | Janet Van Fleet | John Brickels | Linda E. Jones | Nancy H. Taplin | Riki Moss | Sally Linder | Sherri Rigby | Susan Larkin | Tom McGlynn | Wendy James | Will Patlove | Kate Longmaid The catalog presents the work of nineteen artists exhibited at Galerie Maison Kasini in Montreal, February 9-March 26, 2011 (EXHIBITION DETAILS HERE), as well as work by an additional sixteen artists. The catalog contains an essay by Ric Kasini Kadour and images and biographical statements about each of the thirty-five artists. Details: ISBN 978-0-9771397-9-8 Publisher: Kasini House Books | 2011 Size: 10.5″x8″ over 40 pages 35 full color images Publication ©2011 Kasini House Books Images ©2011 by their respective creators (see list above)

name: Sally Linder: Paintings 1992-2009
description: On September 9th, 2001, Sally Linder was at Shelburne Farms in Vermont unveiling the Ark of Hope she made to hold the Earth Charter, a declaration of fundamental principles for building a just, sustainable and peaceful global society for the 21st century. Guest speakers included primatologist Jane Goodall, peace activist Satish Kumar, and Earth Charter Commissioner Steven C. Rockefeller. Paul Winter graced the site with his music and Floating World Dancers performed. Two days later, on September 11th, 2001, in a spontaneous response to the events in New York, Pennsylvania and Washington, DC, Sally Linder began walking the 500 pound Ark of Hope from Vermont to New York City. Hundreds of people participated in the walking journey that lasted two months, covered 350 miles through four states and included sailing on Pete Seeger’s sloop Clearwater. The Ark of Hope was exhibited at the United Nations in January and February 2002. Sally Linder’s journey began much earlier. While traveling native lands in Arizona and Montana, Linder was moved to paint “Manifest Destiny”, a series of work about the American Indian experience. Upon hearing of an electrical fire at the Philadelphia Zoo that killed 23 primates, she painted their portraits and then with the help of the indigenous Dayak, Antandroy, and Bakweri, the 14 paintings of the 23 primates were buried in the jungles of Borneo, Madagascar, and Cameroon. Along with these performative acts, Linder created abstract, meditative paintings that reflect, what Cameron Davis calls, a “clarity of deep listening.” The book documents the creative progress of Vermont artist Sally Linder. Her subjects are inspired by Earth’s beauty and the social and political issues that confront humankind. Her journey has taken her from the canyons of Arizona to the jungles of Borneo to the United Nations. Sally Linder: Paintings 1992-2009 is more than a collection of paintings, it is a document of an artist’s ability to listen and respond to the world around them with impact, power, and remarkable sensitivity. This catalogue was published in conjunction with the exhibition, “Pilgrimage: Remote and Inner Landscapes”, held April 2-May 1, 2010 at the Firehouse Gallery in Burlington, Vermont. The volume includes introductory text by Amanda Sanfilippo and essay by Cameron Davis. Details: 11″x8.5″ | 110 pages | 104 images | ISBN: 978-0-9865298-2-5 | 2010

name: JIMMY Issue #1: Male Intimacy
description:
JIMMY, a new queer zine from California, is a forty-to-fifty page, 5.25″x8.25″ postcard from the L.A. underground. Issue Number One: Male Intimacy features some articles and interviews including one with Brian Hill, the gay drummer of the straight-band, The Soft Pack; a photo spread of musician Allen Bleyle; a photo essay by Quentin Belt of some skinny boys doing laundry; an interesting quote about pet ownership by Jonathan Smith; and an advice column called “Ask Grace.”

Independently published in the hills of Silver Lake and the heart of Hollywood, this quarterly explores the rich and diverse creative talents of the sprawling city of Los Angeles. Through photo editorials, interviews, art, and articles it discovers and promotes L.A.’s underground queer community. In a blog-cluttered world, JIMMY stands as a printed history, preserving and documenting a unique and city-specific cultural moment.

Details: 5.25″x8.25″ | 45 pages | black & white with glossy color cover | Published in Los Angeles, California, USA  | April 2011

description:
We like contemporary issues, settings and ideas. We want our writers to articulate or define what is here, what brought ‘it’ here, where ‘it’ could go in the future and how they feel in regards to ‘it’, themselves or their position in the world.

Volume One deals with a variety of themes such as the Internet, existential paranoia, unpronounceable names, behavioral patterns, suicide and war, the power of objects, fleeting friends, logical roleplaying, imaginary images, sexual experiences through books and questionable kidnappings.

name: Big Winner by Carl David Ruttan
description:
Details: Folio of 10 prints, each 10″x8″ | Digital prints with signed and numbered cover sheet in 10.5″x8.5″ folder in plastic sleeve | Edition of 50 | 2011

A consummate traveler, Carl David Ruttan makes collages with graphic ephemera he finds along the way: Chinese cigarette cartons, Indian candy wrappers, torn bits of music posters from the street. Working in a rented room in Berlin, a youth hostel in Switzerland, on the beach in India, or his apartment in Montreal, Ruttan spreads out the fragments and brings the bits and pieces together in composition. When done, he slides the small 3.75” x 2.75” collages into a plastic sleeve. At Atelier Circulaire in Montreal, Ruttan scans them at extremely high resolution, and produces one unique print to accompany the original collage as the final, archivally stable work of art. The final photographic quality print creates a convincing tactile optic which the eye perceives as an original collage.

Multi-layered, texture-rich colour compositions are composed from the colours and images that printed media lay before the artist as he navigates the sea of symbols around him. They are both the vehicle for self-expression, and limiting agent, determining the palette and tiny details of paper quality that will define the final work.

“Big Winner” is a collection of ten small prints that showcase Ruttan’s approach to collage and printmaking. The edition is limited to fifty.

Carl David Ruttan was born in 1976 in Oshawa, Ontario. He studied fine art at the University of Ottawa, completing his Bachelors of Fine Art in 2000. He has traveled extensively in Asia, North America, Europe and on numerous islands of the Caribbean and South Pacific. Carl settled in Montreal in 2001 after his first trip to Asia. Ruttan is an active member of both the printmaking workshop Atelier Circulaire and Montreal artist-run centre articule.

name: 2009 Papirmasse–Complete Set
description: Papirmasse is a magazine, original artwork, and social experiment all rolled into one. We want everyone to have art – real art! Not the fake paintings sold at department stores or the same tired old posters every college student has. No! We want images to travel and people to get excited about seeing. Down with blank walls; Up with Affordable Art! Papirmasse is art by subscription. Each month, a new issue is sent to subscribers. We are pleased to offer the full set of 2009 Papirmasse prints. These prints are all limited edition – each one is numbered and signed by the artist. They are printed using a combination of offset lithography and digital printing. There is a great variety in the sizes, for all the nooks and crannies in your home. Sizes range from 4″ x 6″ to 18″ x 24″. Details: Folio measuring 12.5″x9.5″ containing 12 archival prints on paper in sizes ranging from 4″ x 6″ to 18″ x 24″ | Printed in Montreal | Edition of 1000 | 2009

name: Photographic Suburbia: Ciaran Brennan
description: Photographic Suburbia: Ciaran Brennan 2008 essay by Ric Kasini Kadour Artist catalog Ciaran Brennan makes art photography: “For most people, a picture… captures something that happened; it is a record. My pictures are a creation of the imagination, not something that happened,” he says. Brennan stages and choreographs the world around him, takes multiple shots, reworks images, and produces photographs that embody the ideas he is trying to express. Brennan’s milieu is North American suburbia and particularly its people and its architecture. Brennan’s solo exhibition at Kasini House in December 2008 was the first significant presentation of his work. DETAILS Title: Photographic Suburbia: Ciaran Brennan Trim Size: 7.5″ x 5.5 ” Binding: Paperback, saddle-stitch Page Count: 28 pages Cover: Full Color Illustrations: 16 full color images Publisher: Kasini House Books Release Date: December 2008 Price: $12.00 About Ciaran Brennan Ciaran Brennan is an engineer by trade, a scientist by education, and a philosopher by nature. Also a father and husband, Ciaran Brennan began making art after taking a course in contemporary art photography at Burlington City Arts in 2005. Brennan participated in the 2007 and 2008 editions of the Art’s Alive Festival of Fine Art as well as the Kasini House 10×10 in July 2007. His work was included in the Danforth Museum Annual Juried Members’ Show in Framingham, MA where he was awarded their First Place Award. He was also included in the New England Photographers Biennial Exhibition at the Danforth Museum. Brennan has a Ph.D in Chemistry from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He lives in Essex Junction, Vermont. About Ric Kasini Kadour Kadour is the former Vermont editor of Art New England and co-author of the Vermont Art Guide. Kadour has contributed writing for a number of books and catalogs; most recently: Lois Eby: From Landscape to Jazz (Galerie Maison Kasini, 2010); Luis London: Reprecussions (Galerie Maison Kasini, 2010); Charles Orme: Icarus & Putto (Galerie Maison Kasini, 2010); Carl David Ruttan: Torn Passages (Galerie Maison Kasini, 2010); Helen Shulman: A Catalog of Recent Paintings (West Branch Gallery, 2009); Craig Mooney: Works on Canvas (West Branch Gallery, 2009); Photographic Suburbia: Ciaran Brennan (Kasini House Books, 2008); “Ethan Murrow’s America” in Ethan Murrow (Obsolete Gallery, 2008); introductory essay in John Matusz: Recent Work (West Branch Gallery, 2007) and “The Epic Journey: Paintings of Giovanna Cecchetti” in Giovanna Cecchetti (West Branch Gallery, 2007).
